name: Le Président. –
text: The next item is the debate with Charles Michel, Prime Minister of Belgium, on the future of Europe. Ladies and gentlemen, today we have here the Prime Minister of the Kingdom of Belgium, Mr Michel. As usual, we will have a real debate with the Prime Minister of a Member State of the European Union. I am pleased to welcome the Prime Minister of Belgium here in Brussels. Thus, we can also debate at the Brussels seat of the European Parliament, and not just in Strasbourg. It is very important for us that Parliament be at the heart of the political debate on the future of Europe. We have welcomed several Heads of State and Government and we had real debates and not just official speeches. I think this is the right way to go ahead and look at what we can do together, Member States, the European Parliament and the Commission. I would also like to thank the President of the European Commission and Commissioner Thyssen for participating in this debate. Once again, I thank Mr Michel for his commitment and for his work. I think it will be very interesting for us to know, the day after the presentation of the European Union budget for 2021-2027, what we think in Belgium on the political issues most important for us all or for the future of Europe, as well as to know Mr Michel's plans for the future.

name: Charles Michel
text: Prime Minister of Belgium. — (FR) Mr President of the European Parliament, ladies and gentlemen, Mr President of the Commission, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, first of all, of course, I would like to thank you for this beautiful initiative that breaks the codes: to offer Heads of State and Government the opportunity to debate directly with MEPs elected by universal suffrage. To provoke the confrontation of ideas, to highlight the stakes and the different visions to understand them, this initiative that is yours is useful and necessary. Ladies and gentlemen, 60 years after the Treaty of Rome, once again, the European Union is facing a pivotal moment and in all our countries — in my own — we feel a sort of paradigm shift. Europe that reassures was an obvious thing for our grandparents after centuries of conflicts and wars. The dividends of peace and prosperity were a concrete reality, valued at its fair value. Today, in the collective imagination, Europe, too often, is associated with frightening globalisation, austerity, opacity or a form of technocracy. In a few years, the reassuring Europe has become a Europe of crises, a Europe that worries — financial, economic crises, debt crisis, migration crisis and even Brexit — the impression of a Europe that is undergoing and which would have lost control of its future and destiny. Yet, in my view, the added value of Europe is real. It is concrete, it is daily, but is it quite visible? Is she noticeable enough? In my opinion, we are facing a crisis of fundamental trust, crisis of trust in public institutions, in general, including European, crisis of trust also towards the traditional media with, in a way, the transparency of social networks which gives a form of illusion with a lot of fake news and also manipulations. Yet trust is the key to democracy. Democracy is a contract between citizens and their representatives. Universal suffrage is legitimacy to decide, to arbitrate, to make choices, and we are confronted — not new in history — with extremists from all sides who waved fears. They disseminate the venom of simplism and caricature to mount peoples against each other, to encourage retreat on oneself and, even sometimes, to try to provoke setbacks on fundamental values. Ladies and gentlemen, I am and I want to be a committed European, but not a naive or blissful European. Europe is better. Crises are managed, growth and investment are gradually resuming, our borders are better controlled, the fight against terrorism is progressing and, more than ever — I want to share this conviction with you — we must return to the original fundamentals of the European idea: to conquer the reason and heart of our compatriots to convince with an ideal but not only with an ideal, to convince with results, namely peace and security, prosperity and equality, freedom and democracy. In my view, these are not hollow words, it is on the contrary a solid and tenacious ambition. This is a promise we are the heirs of. It is a promise that, day after day, we must honour. For this reason, my conviction is that, more than ever, the hour of choice has come. I want to summarize them in three simple questions to which I want to give my part of the committed answer. What do we want to do together, how and with whom? First question: what do we want to do together? I want a strong Europe based on 27 solid states, not a Europe that takes care of everything, always and all the time, but a Europe that acts whenever its added value is real. Rather than a vain battle of sovereignty, the Member States against the European Union, I prefer to choose another path which is that of political primacy. Political and democratic primacy in the Member States and within the European Union. We must, I believe, break this spiral of a perception of democratic powerlessness and we must demonstrate with results the complementary added value of the action of the European Union and of each of our democracies national. Our European, national, regional and local democracies must complement each other and reinforce each other. In the same way, we must constantly coincide the solidarity of all with the responsibility of everyone. Ladies and gentlemen, I identify three demands to give new impetus to this European alliance: prosperity, security and European values. First, the requirement for prosperity. Prosperity must be stimulated and encouraged. We must complete Banking Union, we must consolidate economic and monetary union in the euro area, we must reduce risks and share them better with each other. In this context, taxation is a national instrument, but tax competition, sometimes outrageous between Member States, is a barrier to collective attractiveness in the euro area. How can I explain to my grocer that he pays a higher tax rate than a net giant who, in turn, generates billions of euros in turnover on European soil? We must continue cooperation on tax evasion and move progressively towards harmonizing the corporate tax base. Belgium supports the principles proposed by the European Commission on FATF and, of course, we are also closely following the work of the OECD in this regard. Ladies and gentlemen, the digital agenda and artificial intelligence are, in my view, pools of opportunities for our continent. In my eyes, absolutely everything, in this regard, is on the table. Let us decide, arbitrate, decide on these issues and thus we will unleash an extraordinary potential for jobs and growth. Global warming is not a shadow of doubt. We only have one planet. The Paris agreements must be implemented, and here too, the energy transition is an opportunity for innovation and for the transformation of our economic model. As a Liberal, very naturally, I support free trade, because from all times history has shown, free trade has fostered harmony among peoples. It has always generated economic and social progress. Free trade is virtuous whenever relations between the parties are fair. Reciprocity on the basis of high social and environmental standards must be our goal. It is in this spirit that I personally fought in my country to ensure the signing of CETA, and it is in the same spirit that I am fighting to defend farmers' concerns about Mercosur. Our farmers cannot be an adjustment variable. Clean public finances, additional investments, jobs, purchasing power are the virtuous equation. Jean-Claude Juncker's initiative to revive investments was indispensable. I also wanted to put my country, Belgium, in this dynamic with an ambitious national investment pact. Economic and social developments go hand in hand. The European Pillar of Social Rights is a step forward, and I would also like to welcome efforts to stimulate convergence of social norms and strengthen cooperation between Member States in this regard. Ladies and gentlemen, I come to the second requirement: security. Ensuring security means guaranteeing the real freedom of every citizen. Ensuring security means defending our values of democracy and the rule of law. Ensuring security is a common, shared responsibility and we must, as soon as possible, equip ourselves with an autonomous, credible response capacity against all forms of threat. We must also continue efforts to secure our external borders. We must also lead our security services to cooperate better, to cooperate more effectively in the fight against terrorism or to combat organized crime. Belgium wants to be a loyal partner within NATO and within the European Union. We want European defence within NATO. PESCO and the European Defence Fund are good instruments for making progress. Our operational capacity must serve our geopolitical values and interests. In Belgium, we have faith in multilateralism and yet multilateralism suffers. International standards and rules of good conduct are less respected. Class action has declined in recent years. Now, more than ever, we need to think and act globally. We must, for example, develop a real neighbourhood strategy, we must better prevent regional conflicts, better anticipate their potential consequences. The Sahel, Syria and Libya are all serious conflicts that can seriously impact our future. We must develop a stronger geopolitical ambition to promote our values and defend our interests in the short, medium and long term. I have a firm conviction in this changing world in which no one can unilaterally impose their point of view anymore: the European Union has a place to take. We can be the engine of renewed multilateralism and we are the driving force behind these great challenges facing mankind: peace, security, development or global warming. Ladies and gentlemen, migration movements are inherent in the history of mankind. We must not fear them, we must apprehend them. Belgium, for a long time, has the ambition to implement a migration policy that combines humanity and firmness. We are fighting illegal migration because it fuels criminal networks and leads to human tragedy, unworthy of our century, but should we not also develop a system of legal and organized migration? Sooner or later, we will not avoid this debate. Ladies and gentlemen, the third requirement, in my view, is that of European values. Since the very first day, the European Union has been based on common values that transcend our differences and identities. A story made of glorious moments and tragic suffering, an intellectual, spiritual, philosophical bubbling, of scholars, thinkers, statesmen, revolutions too, Voltaire, Montesquieu, the thought of the Enlightenment. These ingredients have generated freedoms, democracy and the rule of law. The European Convention on Human Rights enshrines the dignity of every individual. It is a light that we must constantly maintain and amplify. More than seventy years ago, in 1946, Winston Churchill, referring to the failure of the League of Nations, said: “If the League of Nations has not succeeded, it is not because these principles were lacking, but because the States that founded it had renounced these principles.” We are committed to democracy and the rule of law as well as the apple of our eyes. For this reason, Belgium proposes the establishment of a peer review mechanism on the rule of law. Specifically, the 27 States would undergo regular scrutiny of the other Member States. It is for each state to look in front of each other. Ladies and gentlemen, we reject all forms of obscurantism, we want an open, knowledge-based society. It is also for this reason that we want to promote and develop a European culture that respects our different identities and our diversity. We need to increase exchanges, go beyond university cooperation, the Erasmus programme must be multiplied and expanded. Make choices, set priorities. The negotiation of the next financial perspective will provide an opportunity to define our perspective on the coming years of the European project. We need to consolidate and modernise common policies, cohesion and support for agricultural policy. We also need to develop new policies: security, innovation, the digital economy, for example. Above all, we have to spend better, spend much better. The European budget will have to be the same thorough rigour as rightly applied by the Commission when it examines our national budgets. We will not accept an additional amount of effort that would jeopardize economic stimulus measures. We'll be realistic. This proposal is a useful starting point, we will analyze in detail the proposals. There is no doubt that these negotiations will be tough and intense. Ladies and gentlemen, I turn to the second question. Any business, to be successful, requires an adequate method. The revision of treaties, in my view, is not necessary in the short or medium term. I think it would even be, in the short or medium term, counterproductive. We need to concentrate all our energy to fulfill the requirements I have just mentioned. Treaties offer enough flexibility to make our response more effective in each of our States. We are confronted with economic, social and political realities at times very different. The deepening of the euro area, migration issues have revealed, sometimes abruptly, a number of realities. I believe deeply in the virtues of true speech. I believe in the virtues of negotiation. We must avoid the unspoken, avoid taboos. Better understanding between us is essential to forge decisions with a wide foundation. We must move forward to twenty-seven because our unity is our strength, but not unity at the price of immobilism because immobilism is the guarantee of backward and regress. I was among the first to advocate for a multi-speed Europe, not to divide, but instead to put a turbo in our decisions. Major advances have often been the result of a vanguard: the euro area, the Schengen area. Multispeed Europe is not a la carte Europe. When you are a member of the club, you derive the benefits, you also assume the responsibilities and constraints. Let us allow those who wish to move forward without forcing those who do not want it or who need more time. I would like, with great frankness in this House, to say how much I am among those who regret a form of hypocrisy of those who systematically turn Europe into scapegoats, without ever having the courage to highlight its results. We must mobilize our fellow citizens. We must avoid debates in isolation. We need to be open to real life. The younger generations must be at the heart of our concerns. Young people are our hope, our strength. Their vitality, their imrelevance, their creativity must be encouraged and I wholeheartedly hope that they will take their full place, that they will occupy the entire space, within the framework of citizens' conventions initiatives. Ladies and gentlemen, the European Union represents a unique project in the history of mankind. It is an imperfect work, it is an incessantly unfinished work. It is above all a promise, a promise for a better world. A better world based on demands: prosperity, security and core values. Putting our public finances in order, embarking on economic, social reforms, taking measures for security, promoting peace are battles of every moment at the service of the European ideal, at the service of European citizens. We need more to promote the culture of result, push back technocracy. We must unlock the potential of our continent, the innovation of our researchers, the creativity of our entrepreneurs, the dynamism of our start-ups and the enthusiasm of our universities. They are formidable weapons at the service of an optimistic and whole future-oriented project. Ladies and gentlemen, sixty years ago visionary statesmen, founding fathers Jean Monnet and Robert Schuman, chose to lay the founders of a project of reconciliation, peace and prosperity. It took them courage, optimism and confidence. Later, on the ruins of the Berlin Wall, the generation led by Helmut Kohl and François Mitterrand or Jacques Delors decided to seal a solid alliance. It laid the foundations for the euro area, opened the Schengen area with tangible progress for our fellow citizens, and it took them courage, optimism and confidence. Today, our political and citizen generation holds in their hands the future of the European dream. After the founding fathers, after the generation of builders, it is up to us to be the entrepreneurs of our common destiny. It is up to us — this is a conviction — to give new impetus. Now it is up to us to implement this promise, this idea which is based on intangible values that we cherish: freedom, dignity, responsibility. It is up to us now to show courage, optimism and trust. (The Assembly, standing, applauds the speaker)

name: Jean-Claude Juncker
text: President of the Commission. — (FR) Mr President, Prime Minister, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, Belgium has a tremendous chance of — as was the case before — a Prime Minister dedicated to the European cause. If I could say the same thing with all the Prime Ministers, we would be in a situation that would be otherwise better than the one we are in. I observe Prime Minister Michel when he evolves in the European Council, I listen to him when we are alone — where important things can be said more easily — and I am always impressed first by his knowledge and mastery of the issues and then by his European convictions which take him far away, and which carry him far away. Belgium in this continental logic to which it subscribes since 1952 without disentumbing. But beyond the person of my friend Charles Michel, I would like to pay tribute to Belgium. Belgium, which, together with Strasbourg and Luxembourg, is home to the European institutions, and welcomes us, the Commission — Parliament will be able to say the same thing with regard to it — with great generosity, especially the Brussels people. This generosity impresses me every day, we are surrounded by Brussels tenderness and we like to live in Brussels. (Applause) I hope that the Belgian authorities will show the same generosity when it comes to granting Belgian nationality to British officials who are here in Brussels. They deserve it. Since I know that the Prime Minister is sometimes overflowing with generosity, I am sure and certain that he will take into account our wishes and remarks. It is in Brussels that all European will converge, the noblest of the European will, and therefore I am pleased to see that in Belgium the debate on Europe is progressing. The Commission is organising citizens' dialogues — just over 650 so far — and I myself have participated in a number of citizens' dialogues in Dutch, French-speaking and German-speaking Belgium, and I know the interest of European citizens in the European thing and I can only encourage the Belgian government and regional governments to continue to do what needs to be done. I have had the opportunity to speak before the House of Representatives. Next week I will speak to the Flemish Parliament and the Walloon Parliament and therefore I will have a heavy Belgian week which, in advance, makes me warm in my heart. I would also like to say how pleased I am to see Belgium taking part in the investment plan, which at one time was called the Juncker Plan. Belgium has so far been able to mobilise between 6, 7 billion and 8 billion investments in the north and south of the Kingdom, so I am very pleased with the Belgian response to the European investment plan. I have, of course, noted the “friendly” remarks expressed with great restraint by the Prime Minister on the budget proposal I presented to you yesterday. Every convinced European will see in the analysis, the autopsy and the detailed examination of the intelligent, wise proposals of the Commission, that it is a budget, a financial framework which obviously does not break the springs of growth, but on the contrary makes the springs that exist in the different countries a chance of deposits of jobs and growth. Let me take as an example the $20 billion we want to spend on structural reforms, or the $30 billion that will be aligned so that we can fight, when necessary, asymmetrical shocks from inside or outside us. It is therefore a budget which obviously deserves not the spontaneous applause of the Belgian government, but a reflection which will allow it not to say no to this budget. In fact, I would like you to say yes right away, but the merits of the proposals that are being made will have to be examined in detail. For the rest, why would I add some remarks to those of the Prime Minister, since on most things, anyway, on everything he said today, we are in complete harmony. That was not surprised to me, and I would like to see from now on, as yesterday and today, we can count on the strong support of Belgium. (Applause)

name: Manfred Weber
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, Belgium is at the heart of Europe – this is the message that welcomes people at Brussels airport. It is at the heart of Europe, but a big ambition I have to say. I thank you for your contribution today about the ‘Future of Europe’ discussion. The idea of the discussion is not to talk about the headlines of today’s newspapers. The idea of this discussion is to talk about the fundamentals of our Union, of our project. Today I want to focus on the foundation of the state structure. Europe is not only built on strong nations; Europe is rooted in every region. And there I think Belgium is a perfect example for this. Regions are our homes. We talk a lot about identity when we talk about Europe. Regions are the place where we take our first steps in the world, where we grow up, where we define and shape our personalities. Our identities are not based simply on national thinking and culture; the European identity is much more than that. The European identity begins in our schools; during a chat at the usual bar; passing the street in our town at home. Europe is really deeply rooted in our regions. Without regions, Europe would be homeless. it is about feelings and about community which we can learn in the regions. it is about participation and responsibility which we can learn in our regions. Without a community, without a region, Europe falls apart. it is precisely the combination of regional diversity that makes Europe unique in the world. But the relationship between Europe and its regions is a two-way love affair. Thanks to the regions, Europe is grounded, but thanks to Europe, regions can take off. I want to give you a few examples. When we speak about the budget of the EU, after the presentation of Jean-Claude Juncker’s proposal for the next Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF), we see absolutely clearly that we spend a lot of money in the development of our regions. The European Regional Development Fund is a key element for our policy in regard to the regions. We don’t want simply to preserve the regions, to keep them still as some sort of history museum, as populists probably would do; we want regions to have a brighter future. We want to have competition between regions, and we want to invest in human capital and innovation, infrastructure and quality of the institutions. A second example: Europe means taking pride in our cultural roots. In a globalised world it is more needed than ever before to do this. Only with Europe we can preserve our regional identities. A third element: Europe means moving regions from the corner to the centre. Most regional potentials would go to waste without connections in the European Union. Europe creates a net of regions that can develop. In fact, some of the most economically-advanced regions in Europe are on the national borders. Think, for example, of the Rhône-Alps region, Lombardi, Lower Silesia, or for example my home region, Bavaria. We can see that many regions have only a real chance thanks to Europe. Europe means to live in safe regions. How else could individual regions deal with the threats of terrorism or the external problems with China and Russia. So Europe shields the regions from a more and more insecure world. I want to add another aspect when we talk about regions. I want to talk about the regional egoism which we see from time to time in Europe. One thing is clear: regional identity is not an excuse for regional egoism. If a region leaves its Member States, it leaves the European Union. Europe is about sticking together for a better future, and that also applies when it comes to being part of a Member State. I know some bureaucrats would say that we can only be efficient if we do more centralisation. Some business leaders would say we would have much more economic success if we do centralisation. I say Europe is built on diversity and not on monotony. Everything that can be done better or just as well at local, regional and national level must be done at the lowest level possible. That’s why I ask for a competence check, to do again an initiative on checking the competences – the distribution of competences – between the regions. Mr Prime Minister, I listened very carefully to your speech. An additional aspect is if we talk about subsidiarity, it is in order to take over responsibility, because when the Member States are deciding – mainly unanimously in the Council – in favour of European legislation, then they cannot complain at home that Europe was deciding on these issues. So both things are important. Let’s keep the power of the regions. For example, we fought here in Parliament to ensure that not big companies have the say about who provides the drinking water for the people when the local level is providing. This was one of the battles which we fought here in the European Parliament. Finally, let’s put the region in the heart of European democracy. Staying close to our citizens means staying close to our region, and that is why we, as parliamentarians, must stick to our homes, our constituency and forget about abstract ideas like we discussed on the transnational list. I am a proud Bavarian. My nation is Germany and I am a European believer. These three elements belong together. Europe has no future if it doesn’t start from its roots. So let’s keep regions in the heart of Europe. (Applause)

name: Kathleen Van Brempt
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, I wish to welcome Prime Minister Michel to the European Parliament, the heart of European democracy. Mr Michel, I welcome you also as a Belgian citizen, being very proud to belong to a country that has stood at the cradle of the European Union. You are my Belgian Prime Minister, but in a sense you are also the Prime Minister of all the people in this Parliament, because half of the time they live in Brussels, they go to our restaurants, they drink Belgian beer...  (Mixed reactions) ... they do. Brussels is not just the capital of Belgium; Brussels is the heart of Europe. In that sense Belgium has given a lot to Europe, but Europe also has also given a lot to Belgium. Prime Minister, that is what Europe is all about. It’s about working together, about solidarity and creating – at least it should create – added value for our Member States, but mostly for our citizens. That is what our group, the Socialists and Democrats, fight for on a daily basis. When we talk about the future of Europe, we want more ambition in the social pillar, Madam Commissioner, we want fair taxation, we want to be a proud Europe in the rest of the world and we want to implement the sustainable development goals when we talk about the multiannual financial framework. Prime Minister, I do not – absolutely do not – doubt your attachment to European values and I heard that in your speech, but I have a big concern, a very big concern, because there’s a huge gap between your very nice speech of today – I do not agree with everything but it was a good speech, it was a pro-European speech – and what Belgium these days does on an everyday basis in the Council.  (Applause) You talked about the corporate tax base, the CCTB, and said you’re in favour, but this morning, on national radio, I was with the NVA – your coalition partner – and they said they are against this, and your Minister of Finance is against more solidarity on taxation in Europe on a daily basis. (Applause) As it is on the financial transaction tax, so it is when it comes to the taxation of the giants of the digital world. That really is of concern. I mean that. Belgium has always been a bridge—builder in Europe – always – connecting the different big Member States to each other. You have lost that, which will be your historical responsibility, and it’s because you have a coalition and back home you need to listen to your big coalition partner, the Flemish nationalists, who are riding more and more on Euroscepticism in Europe. That really is a big concern to me. Mijnheer de eerste minister, ik ga over naar mijn moedertaal, die u zeer goed kent en zeer goed spreekt. Ik apprecieer dat enorm. Dat is ook iets Europees, verschillende talen spreken.  Ik wil nog een laatste belangrijk punt aanstippen. Als ik hier met mijn collega’s spreek en ze hebben het over België, dan komt heel snel het probleem van de nucleaire veiligheid naar boven. Mijn Franse, mijn Duitse collega's, mijn Nederlandse collega's liggen meer wakker van de nucleaire veiligheid dan de Belgische regering en dat kan niet langer! (Applaus) Het wordt hoog tijd dat de Belgische regering daar de juiste ....– mijnheer Loones u schudt uw hoofd. Neen! Deze week nog is er in Doel 1 opnieuw een lekkage. Een nucleaire installatie met scheurtjes is onaanvaardbaar. En, mijnheer de eerste minister, ook daar moet je de Europese kaart trekken. Nucleaire veiligheid is niet de verantwoordelijkheid alleen van een lidstaat. Dat doe je in nauwe samenwerking met alle lidstaten en zeker met je buurlanden. Mijnheer de eerste minister, ik reken op u om de kerncentrales zeer snel te sluiten.

name: Sander Loones
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. — (NL) Thank you, Mr President, especially to Prime Minister Michel of Belgium, for your speech here in the European Parliament. Thank you, above all, for not giving that speech in Strasbourg, but here in Brussels, in the capital of the European Union, and I think that all Members of Parliament who always vote to abolish this Strasbourg moving circus would be satisfied and should be here to give your speech to follow. Prime Minister, I am speaking today on behalf of our group, the European Conservatives and Reformists. And yes, I am also speaking as vice-chairman of my party, the N-VA, as has just been mentioned for those who do not know the situation. In Belgium, we run the N-VA together, the party of Prime Minister Michel and our party. We think the same about a number of issues, as always is the case, and we differ on other issues. In fact, cooperation with the European Union is one of those issues where we do differ slightly on various points. Unity in diversity. That is the motto of European cooperation. Your party is defending that unity, that European harmonisation. In my party, we cherish more diversity. We see the European Union as a partnership of sovereign countries, of regions, each with its own tradition, each with its own culture, its own identity and healthy competition between those regions, between those countries, which ensures that European cooperation can really flourish. It was very pleasant, Mr Weber, to hear your praise to the regions, to this cultural diversity, to that cultural identity which is the richness of European cooperation. But, Prime Minister, we differ on a number of points. At the same time, you're a sensible man. That's how I know you, and I know you as a politician who is convinced of European cooperation, and that is where we find each other. So you opt for a more realistic approach. We have not heard a speech today with unbridled European activism. We haven't heard any European air castles. What we have heard is a more realistic speech, because you realise that with these castles we will not convince the people. The result of this change in vision is that Belgium's voice in the European and international debate does indeed sound a bit different in recent years. The voice of Belgium sounds a bit more northern European than it used to be, with a little more common sense. When I look at the European budget, for example. For the first time, Belgium is presenting itself as a net contributor. That never happened in the past. We are also a net contributor. We will therefore also have to look at expenditure thoroughly, analyse it and save where it is necessary, as you rightly point out. In your speech, you also spoke of European values and that we must defend them, including within Europe. We agree on that, too. For you, and that really pleases me, values are not vague principles. For you, that is something very concrete, something very tangible. You will also stand up for that, even when others doubt or let it down. We saw that, for example, during the referendum in Catalonia. Then, Prime Minister Michel, you were the first head of government, the very first to condemn violence, the violence of police officers, Spanish police violence against innocent people who are going to vote. You have condemned this and rightly so, because violence against innocent people is simply anti-European, that is against our European values. In the area of migration, too, we see that there is change in Belgium. We are now back on the right side for a stricter and more rigorous policy. We are not advocating open borders. On the contrary. We see that parties that do lose the support of the population for this. They are also losing the elections, as it appears in several European countries. And then there is the big thing, the future of the euro area. The big debate for the next few months. I am pleased to note that Belgium, too, is more and more on the side of the realists. We need to improve the functioning of the euro area, but nobody is waiting for European films. That is why our government does not want a European Ministry of Finance. We do not want a large eurozone budget and European taxes. That is why we really need to ask whether this is such a good idea for the support of the European Union. Union. I don't think so. Now, as has been said, there are similarities between our parties. There are also differences. You are more approaching solidarity, we are a little more responsible. You rightly emphasise that taxation and social security are the competences of Member States. At the same time, you would like to support the CCTB, which is something more to the benefit of the large Member States of the European Union. We believe that we should be able to defend jobs in small Member States and that we should not lose them. But I do see differences, but above all many points of contact and therefore I would like to end with a call. We know you have a good relationship with President Macron of France. Yet you don't bring the same story. You come up with a story that is actually a little closer to what the citizens of Europe want today and are able to handle today. And I would like to call, Prime Minister Michel: stand! Continue to bring that realistic story and you will see that you will find strong partners, more and more in this European Union. You will also find those partners with such a story in our European group, the European Conservatives and reformers, if you choose unity, but in diversity. In variety!

name: President. –
text: Mr Loones, it is possible to be against the European Parliament having two seats, to be in favour of only one seat. But Strasbourg is not a circus; it is one of the seats of the European Parliament.

name: Guy Verhofstadt
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. — (FR) Mr President, I will first start in the mother tongue of Charles Michel, our Prime Minister, to say to him that I thank him for his pro-European vision. I like your speech more than the interpretation given by Mr. Loones. Apparently Mr Loones heard another speech, I do not know which one, but a speech which was delivered in the Flemish Parliament or the Federal Parliament of Belgium. I would therefore like to thank you for your pro-European vision, as you have expressed it, in the great pro-European tradition that exists in Belgium. The vision of one of our predecessors and I always quote Paul-Henri Spaak, who said: “All European countries are small but there are two categories: those who know it and those who do not yet know it”. This is a great reality and it is our approach, as Belgians, to European policy. Indeed, ladies and gentlemen — I will explain it to you because Mr Loones has not done so — that for Belgians, whether Flemish, Walloon or Brussels, to be pro-European — what we are — is not a matter of choice, it is an existential question. Our country, our lands have been the battlefield for all of Europe too long, stuck as we were between Germany on the one hand, and France on the other. They all came to us: the French, the Germans — twice — the Spaniards, the Dutch, the Austrians, and even the Italians if I go back to the time of the Romans, but maybe it's too far in the past. All the great conflicts — and it's not a joke — in European history have fought here on these lands: wars of religion, wars of succession, trench wars with millions of deaths, and the first use of gas and chemical weapons in the world, 100 km from here. Not to mention, of course, the war against Nazism — the worst of all nationalisms. It is therefore clear that for us — I want to say this directly to Mr Loones, who has not yet understood it — there is only one possible future for our lands and for our peoples: a common future and a European destiny. Everything else, Prime Minister — needless to tell you — are lies, cheating, dreams that quickly become nightmares, as we saw in the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries. Only Europe can save us from this misery and atrocities of the past. I tell you all this, ladies and gentlemen, to tell you that it is not chocolate, that it is not beer, that it is not Tintin, that it is not the cursed system that you all know — because you apply it — which are typically Belgian, no, it is our love for Europe, it is our passion for the European project which are typical of our country. A project, Mr President, which is threatened today, not only by nationalists and populists — we know them and we see them almost every day, they are among our colleagues — but also by political leaders at the national level, which is also found in all the political families represented in this House. Political leaders — I am not talking about you, you are one of the few exceptions — who appear outward as pro-European, but who actually do nothing to move the project forward. I would say they are doing the opposite today, which is a dishonour to the founding fathers of the European Union who had a different vision of Europe than the one we know today. So it is wrong to say that people do not like Europe; people like Europe, but they do not like the European Union as it works today. That is the problem for them, as was observed again yesterday. I will now move into the language of Vondel, as they say, Dutch. We hebben dat nog de laatste maal gisteren gezien, mijnheer de voorzitter van de Commissie. Een aantal reacties zeggende: 1,11% van het Europese bruto binnenlands product dat is veel te veel! Europa wordt kleiner, by Britten gaan eruit. Het is niet eleven beslissing geweest, due moet het een kleiner budget zijn. Wel, ik zeg u heel openlijk in tot alle collega's: de waarheid is het omgekeerde! Ik wil enkele redenen geven. Om de crisis te beheren, die we vandaag kennen — of het nude de migratiecrisis, de geopolitieke crisis of de financiële crisis is die morgen opnieuw kan toeslaan — daarvoor hebben we méér Europa nodig en niet minder Europa, om die crisis te bestrijden. Wij hebben een Europese grens- in kustwacht nodig. We hebben een Europese defensie nodig. Wij hebben inderdaad een Europees budget nodig voor de eurozone. From actie van Europa kost niet meer geld. Die laat ons in feite geld besparen. Want to veel van de uitgaven die in feite niet nodig zijn, gebeuren op nationaal level, omdat eleven national lidstaten 28 keer hetzelfde doen vandaag! Terwijl Europa daar en meerwaarde zou kunnen hebben. Ik heb zovele voorbeelden. From military uitgaven. Mijnheer Vandeput kan het u vertellen. Hij heeft het u ongetwijfeld al verteld. We are also 42% on the van de Amerikaanse uitgaven. We slechts 10 tot 15% van de Amerikaanse operaties. Waarom? Omdat we het 28 keer doen. Hetzelfde geldt voor bijvoorbeeld het beheer van de buitengrenzen. Mijnheer of voorzitter van de Commissie, u heeft gisteren het voorstel gedaan. We gaan 34 miljard euro uitgeven voor een beter beheer van eleven buitengrenzen op zeven jaar tijd. De Amerikanen geven 34 miljard dollar uit op één jaar tijd om hetzelfde te doen. Ik nodig al eleven national regeringsleiders uit om hier in dit parliament te komen zeggen dat het beheer van eleven buitengrenzen geen prioriteit moet zijn van de Europese United waarvoor nieuw geld moet worden vrijgemaakt. Ik nodig ze uit om dat hier te komen zeggen tegenover hun eigen kiezers. Europa is niet of vijand van of burgers. Europa is de beste zekerheid die de burgers kunnen hebben. In ik vraag u, mijnheer de eerste minister, laat dit nooit verloren gaan. Want zelfs of Duits-Franse motor alleen kan het niet trekken. De beste motor heeft ook nood aan olie, aan vet, met andere woorden aan het Belgische compromised, en kunst die u zo goed beheerst.

name: Le Président. –
text: Please, I ask you to respect your speaking time or I will have to delete the names of some members of the group from the list. I'm flexible with the group leader but you have to try to limit yourself: you talked eight minutes, Guy.

name: Philippe Lamberts
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. — (FR) Mr President, however, it is curious that every time I turn comes, you remind you that speaking time must be respected, but I do not think I am the worst offender. Prime Minister, in our country the commitment to European integration is evident. Belgium alone weighs little against Putin or Trump. It is not important to face the climate challenge or the power of multinationals. Acting with our European neighbours is obvious if we want to forge our future, rather than suffer it. For decades, Belgium has lived up to this ambition by playing a pioneering role. In the context of the current crisis, it would be expected to redouble its efforts. Yet, Mr Prime Minister, despite the words you have spoken, your action shows a Belgium which too often confines itself to observing, dragging behind, when it does not overwhelm initiatives for greater integration. Voorzitter, het kan anders. Wij dromen van België als voortrekker in de Europese strijd tegen fiscal en social dumping. Een België dat samen met Europese partners aan multinationals maximum transparency oplegt. Een België dat een coalition of the willing puts France en Duitsland zal volgen om een Europese harmonisatie van bedrijfsbelastingen mogelijk te maken. Maar helaas, úw regering werd twee maanden geleden door de Europese Commissie met de vinger gewezen als een van de zeven lidstaten die aggressieve fiscal optimalisatie stimulleert. Samen twee buurlanden ondermijnt from Benelux zo de Europese pogingen om meer fiscal rechtvaardigheid te creëren. En intussen organiseert úw minister van Financiën in alle stilte de begrafenis van de financiële transactietaks. We dream of a Belgium that demonstrates to Europe that it is possible to combine budgetary responsibility and reduce inequality. A Belgium capable of maintaining high quality public services while transforming our taxation so that they are financed fairly by everyone to the extent of their capabilities. But no, Belgium remains a tax haven for the ultra-rich fleeing tax in their country and for multinationals. Even though workers in this country are among the most taxed in Europe and in the world, your government refuses to recover 942 million euros of illegal tax gifts. At the same time, the quality and accessibility of public services are deteriorating, social security and justice, essential pillars of our life in society, become the adjustment variables of your strategy. Voorzitter, wij dromen van een België als koploper van de ecologische transitie, want to dár ligt de sleutel van onze welvaart en die van de toekomstige generaties. Yesterday de duurzame oplossingen uitvinden en toepassen in plaats van de rest van de wereld zitten te wachten. Werken aan een energie-onafhankelijkheid van Europa om niet meer te steunen op gas uit Rusland en olie uit Saoedi-Arabië. Dát zijn uitdagingen die Europese burgers kunnen enthusiasmeren. Maar helaas, Belgium verloor alle geloofwaardigheid door zonder klimaatplan naar de Parijse klimaatconferentie te gaan. A verzamelde ezelsoren van de Europese Commissie door te weinig ambitie inzake klimaat, luchtkwaliteit of de groeiende files. Eleven buurlanden zijn bezorgd over ons koppig openhouden van stokoude kerncentrales aan eleven grenzen. Vorige week nog bleek dat uw overheid insecticiden wil blijven toestaan waarvan bewezen is dat ze dodelijk zijn voor bijen! We dream of a Belgium up to the challenge of asylum and migration, a Belgium that supports the European Parliament in putting an end to this senseless Dublin system. A Belgium in solidarity with the Member States at the borders of Europe, left alone in the face of migratory challenges. A Belgium that welcomes and integrates those who knock on our doors in need. But no! You prefer to work with the Sudanese dictator to send him people fleeing hell. It is not surprising since, among your allies, some want to question the Geneva Convention, the central pillar of the right to asylum. You prefer to spend ever more on locking up, pushing and deporting human beings because they don't have the right papers, because they are not born in the right place. You say your policy is firm and human. Rather than firm, I would say violent, rather than human, I would say unworthy. Humanity does not come from your government, Mr Michel, it comes from our fellow citizens who have assumed their responsibilities to welcome home those who flee war and misery. They honour our country, where your government shames it. Prime Minister, this Belgium of which we environmentalists dream and want is possible. But in this country, as everyone knows, it is not the Greens who are in power, it is not even you, Prime Minister, because you have chosen to entrust your fate and that of our country to a national-populist party, which everyone knows that he and himself alone set the course. With the highly Eurosceptic N-VA, you choose each for himself, worse yet, each against all. In the face of the challenges of this century, Prime Minister, we stand for boldness and solidarity. The contrast cannot be stronger, the clearer alternative.

name: Gabriele Zimmer
text: Mr President, Prime Minister Mr President, on behalf of my group, I too would like to welcome you to this discussion, which is, of course, a debate on the future of the European Union and has been in this way. What I would like to make clear at the beginning: Brussels and Belgium have indeed been the gateway to Europe for me. I am one of those — at least from those who are sitting here answering in the first round — who came to Europe from an Eastern European point of view and understood that Europe does not end at the former borders, but that we can learn, must learn that different historical experiences, traditions and cultural understanding also belong to each other, and that the EU is that Europe cannot live without this diversity. We must and will continue to stand for this. It is interesting to me that — and this is also somewhat ill in the debate for me — we are actually able to bring into this from these different perspectives the experience and expectations that we associate with the European Union in very different ways. We are witnessing here today — and this is not the first time, and it is very justified, and I take note of this so easily — that many Belgian Members are, of course, having their discussions with you — from a strictly European perspective. All right! I see, however, that others hardly get involved here today. My group suffers from the fact that we do not have a Belgian Member. I promise you, this will be different with the next election. The next time you come to the European Parliament, if you are still a Minister or Prime Minister, you are guaranteed to hear one of the Belgian MEPs from the left here. I am glad to be able to do it today from the point of view of people who have joined, have great expectations of the European Union — and who still have — who want to continue, but who are dissatisfied, dissatisfied with the current state of the development of the Union and with what we experience every day, and I would have been dissatisfied with the current state of development of the Union and with what we experience every day. I would be delighted if you had addressed these contradictions much more strongly. It cannot be overlooked, however, that we have regions within the European Union where the concept of social neglect has to be used. We have a presidency by Bulgaria. I do not know who has been to Bulgaria outside the official meetings with the institutions, with the representatives of the Government of Bulgaria in recent months and has had to take note that it is not only Bulgaria, but many other regions in other countries too, that we have a deep difference between the Expectations of the Union, between the daily lives that people in the Union have, divisions are growing. That's what we have to go into. And it is not enough for me to say, Prime Minister: we have done many things again in the meantime, we are out of the strongest crises, and we are moving forward and we are committed to this, and we want to invest more and do so. That's not good for me! I would like to hear a very clear promise from all the Heads of Government who are here: what is being done to get us out of this situation and what real added value is there for each individual? They rightly spoke of the importance of including freedom, justice in particular, and freedom cannot exist without individual freedom for each individual. Political freedoms belong together as well as the rights to fundamental social rights, the right to have rights. This does not have to be separated, however, this must be merged. That is my claim, and I would like to have an answer from every single head of government here: what are you doing to enforce this? I have learned from Mr Juncker that if you meet them in the Council and knock on their backs, you can also welcome Heads of Government in a very subtle way and say that my favourite dictator is here now. But that's practically only one side, so we didn't solve the problem. I don't expect you to do this, but I want to you already know what you are doing in the Council, for example, on the one hand, to persuade Orbán and others to ensure that this shared responsibility, which you have mentioned, is also borne in the face of the refugee problem, with regard to the rule of law, autonomy, Independence from courts and media. On the other hand, what are you doing to develop concrete ideas, for example, that we are coming out of what we are currently experiencing? The fact that it is always said that the Treaties prevent us from assuming shared social responsibility and solidarity. I want to know. They say that the Treaties cannot be opened, and in the short term this is counterproductive. Yeah, please, how then? We have witnessed — and this is my view and also the point of view of many colleagues in my group: from treaty to treaty, in my view, the EU's options for action to shape the future have been reduced. They have diminished, but we have to reopen them. We must make it open, make it possible for social and solidarity to be shared, because we cannot allow regions of social neglect to exist in the middle of the European Union. Without fundamental social rights, people will not get involved either. Nor will they stand up for their liberties. They say to themselves: I don't care who is leading the government in Bulgaria now. The ones before, now — no one cares about us. We allow some of the people to be exempted from the Union because they do not meet the requirements of the free movement rules. That's exactly what we have to turn to. My final word: also look at the people from Eastern Europe who sat as homeless people in Berlin, Paris and London, and whom we as the Union now refuse to help. That can't be!

name: Nigel Farage
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, it is quite extraordinary that we can have in this room the head honchos of Brussels – Mr Juncker, the Belgian Prime Minister, the leaders of the big groups, to discuss the future of the European project, and there has barely been a mention of the biggest most dramatic event that has ever happened since the foundation of the European Treaties 60 years ago, namely Brexit.  You do not want to talk about Brexit. And I wonder whether it actually ever occurred to you, Mr Juncker, that when David Cameron came here to negotiate with you, had you given him just a few modest concessions, had you given him the ability to control our borders a little bit more, Brexit would not have happened. But no, we don’t discuss that. No, what we do, is we say to ourselves that our citizens want more Europe. I have heard it again and again this morning. We have a problem with unemployment among the youth of the Mediterranean. I know the answer: more Europe. We have a problem with growing terrorism in our countries, something that we have caused ourselves but we decide, no, the answer is, or in the case of the Belgian Prime Minister Michel, to have a European CIA. We decided that on taxation, on regulation, no Member State can make their own decisions, it has all got to be decided here in Brussels, because we need more Europe. In fact, many of you have decided that migrant quotas are a good idea, so that individual Member States cannot make their own decisions, so is it any wonder that there are countries now, voters everywhere, waking up to the idea that you cannot be an independent democratic nation state – and a member of this Union.  Brexit, I think, is going to prove to be just the first brick that is knocked out of the wall. Just look at the results in Italy a few weeks ago. Look at the stunning results in Hungary the other week. That magnificent victory of Viktor Orbán and about 70% of voters in Hungary voting for parties that want the nation state to be the key to everything. If you really think about whether this European project can survive, or not, it all comes down to ‘what is a nation’? What is the unit towards which we give our allegiance, to which we pay our taxes, to which we would, in extremis, be prepared to defend them? There are some like Mr Verhofstadt here who seem to think that this flag represents a European identity – and he clearly identifies as a European, many of you in this room identify as Europeans – but you are missing something. The peoples of Europe do not identify with that flag. They do not identify with these institutions. There is no, oh well if you’re on the payroll it’s easy to say it works, isn’t it? But actually, out there in the real world, there is not a European demos, there is not a European identity,  But there may be one exception, and that could be Belgium. Because nobody ever dares tell the truth about Belgium. Belgium is not a nation. It is an artificial creation. I know the Brits did it, maybe once again we can be blamed, but the truth is there are two parts of Belgium, they speak different languages, they dislike each other intensely, there is no national TV station, there is no national newspaper. Belgium is not a nation. And maybe that is why you are happy to sign up to a higher European level. Well, if Belgium wants it, that is fine, but I can assure you, and you can scream and shout all you like, just look at the election result. You are losing votes. You are losing. Brexit is the first brick out of the wall. You’ve learned none of the lessons. The days of this project are over. We want to live in nation states, not false artificial creations.  Thank you everybody. Have a lovely time. Oh, and enjoy the European elections next year, they’re going to be great fun.

name: Presidente. –
text: Hon. Farage, I remind you that you also take the salary as a Member of the European Parliament, like everyone else. So it's not like others are paid and she's not, I don't understand that she has waived her allowances, neither you nor her group.

name: Nigel Farage (EFDD).
text: – With respect, Mr President, I supported Britain leaving the European Union. Therefore, with my job ending, I am the turkey that voted for Christmas. (Applause from certain quarters)

name: Presidente. –
text: As you said that those who support Europe do so because they are paid, I told you that you too receive salary as a European parliamentarian.

name: Gerolf Annemans
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. — (NL) Mr President, I myself have served 30 years in the Belgian Parliament, but I have never been interviewed there by a President and I hope that this will not happen again today. For the rest, I have little to add to Mr Farage. First I want to protest against the Prime Minister — I can't see him well, but he will hear me, I hope — a little bit. There is interpretation in this House, but you have heard here today that many people do not speak their mother tongue. So, apparently, that's not your excuse. So the fact that you have spoken here today only in French is a political choice. I will ask my colleagues from the Flemish Belang in the Flemish Parliament and the federal parliament why N-VA ministers allowed Belgium to be presented here again as a French-speaking state. Secondly, as an ENF representative, I am not surprised at all. Belgium is always the good and sweet boy in the classroom, the girl in the class who sits at the front and always raises the finger and never really makes a big history, except to push the whole forward. No wonder that today Mr Juncker congratulated you, Prime Minister. In fact, your government makes no exception to that statute of Belgium which, in all invisibility, always, as Mr Verhofstadt has explained here with arms and feet, is pro-European, extremely pro-European and perhaps essentially pro-European. Belgium and the European Union, it's a love affair. The European Union thinks it is Belgium in large size and Belgium thinks it is the European Union in small size. This is a logical order, because it is an artificial state which is as unbalanced as the European Union itself and which is also held together with money and with financial agreements, compensation and transfers. So in that love affair there's a certain logic. The debate for the rest of today has clearly illustrated one thing. And that is the great disease of this European Union and of this cathedral of the European Union, namely that at home people say something different from what they are doing here. We have seen this illustrated today by Mr Loones, a representative of your coalition's largest coalition party, Mr Michel. He tells something different from what he is doing here at home, or at least we do not see the results of what is being told at home on the radio and in the television studios where the N-VA will undoubtedly pretend in the coming weeks it is a shame that more money should go to the European Union, as if It is a shame that a new European Union tax system is approaching. But if he enters this cathedral, when his Prime Minister speaks here, we will not hear or see any more of it. The same applies to immigration where the Secretary of State for Migration at home and in television studios pretends to be critical of immigration. There's nothing left of that. Then Charles Michel arrives here and he turns Belgium into a beautiful Pinkcloud Europe and European Union country. So that is not true! Indeed, Mr Farage is right. The people are protesting against this, and one can only keep a Belgian government alive if one lies at home about what they come to do here. When people say something different at home and enter the cathedral of the federal Union, they do so behind federal music. Conclusion: all criticisms made by N-VA, all the criticisms you will hear, Prime Minister, for the media gallery in Belgium in the coming weeks, are nothing but sand in the eyes and clean appearance for the Flemish voters. Because when it comes to shove, the N-VA, as it has done here today, in the person of Mr Loones, is the first right to give you a standing ovation and to sing European federal music here. That is the big difference between reality and the beautiful appearance in one's own country. That is also at the heart of the European Union's problems, that all those who sing federal music here go back to their home country with two faces, and that is not what the electorate wants.

name: Le Président. –
text: Ladies and gentlemen, everyone is free to say what they want in this debate, but I remind you that the debate is about the future of Europe, not the future of Belgium.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI).
text: — Welcome, Prime Minister! Those who believe in the idea of a United Europe that strives to serve the needs and interests of its nations and peoples are concerned about the path the European Union is taking, and hence its future. They wonder what future the European Union can have when it has deviated from the principles and values on which its creation was based, when it denies its historical, religious and cultural origins, when it violates the principle of solidarity, with a typical example of Greece is also responsible for the economic destruction of which the European Union is responsible for the impoverishment of the Greek people; when, instead of supporting its citizens, it turns against them, imposes unbearable taxes on them, removes social benefits and imposes a hijacking of their property; when criminalising and prosecuting any opposing voice; when it dismisses the education of young people and prompts them either to immigration, unemployment, or to part-work under poor conditions and at very low pay. What future can it have when it uncontrollably accepts millions of illegal immigrants, part of which is trying to trap in Greece? Finally, what future can it have when it is supposedly fighting for the principles of democracy and wants to integrate Turkey, an undemocratic country which blackmailed, threatens, does not recognise the Republic of Cyprus, arrests citizens of the European Union, with a recent example the arrest and imprisonment of the two Greek military troops. I shall end by asking you, Prime Minister: Do you believe that the leadership circle of the European Union has the will and the strength to improve the bad texts I have mentioned?

name: Charles Michel
text: Prime Minister of Belgium. — (FR) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all I would like to thank you for the excellent interventions and reactions in this debate. I'll try to react to one or the other point. Mr Weber, you praised the regional dimension. As I said in my message, I think there is no sense in wanting to oppose the different democracies — local, regional, national and European. In my country, in Belgium, we also have a tradition of forging the positions defended at European level, of organising a regular, permanent consultation on the various issues. The message I deliver on behalf of Belgium is a message that also takes into account the different political, regional and local sensitivities on the future of the European Union. First point. Second, it was said, compliments were sent and criticisms were made. I am used to, I debate from time to time in the Belgian Parliament as well; it is not otherwise. We are committed at European level. I am personally committed to the European level, not for a romantic, beate Europe, disconnected from reality, but for a Europe that is really focused on an ambition for results. Results for fundamental issues. Geachte collega's, we zijn ervan overtuigd dat Europa meer en meerwaarde kan en moet zijn voor meer welvaart voor eleven medeburgers, meer jobs en meer koopkracht. We zijn overtuigd dat wij wat veiligheid betreft meer moeten samenwerken. Guy Verhofstadt heeft gelijk. Wat defensie betreft hebben we de laatste maanden belangrijke vooruitgang geboekt. Dat gaat in goede richting. Belgium is daar zeer geëngageerd. We proberen daar een zeer sterke rol te spelen. In zeker, migratie is een moeilijke uitdaging, die vraagt om een genuanceerd antwoord. Ik wil mijnheer Lamberts zeggen... Mr Lamberts, I expected some outrances from you. So far you have not succeeded in getting elected to the Belgian Parliament, you have the opportunity to be outrageous here and you have not missed this opportunity. I have no lesson to be learned from a political party in Belgium which caused the photovoltaic bubble in the energy sector by sending billions of euros of bills to Walloon taxpayers. I also want to fully accept the difficult decisions we are making, like other European countries, on migration. We assume our responsibilities. Asylum applications are actually lodged in Belgium. They are treated in accordance with international, European and national rules. We have no lesson on the subject and we assume the real subject. Indeed, we believe that we will not escape a debate on channels of legal, orderly migration. Indeed, we believe that this debate should take place and we are prepared to conduct it with a very committed commitment. Finally, some Belgian inquiries on nuclear safety. Ik wil zeer kort ingaan, mevrouw Van Brempt, op de nucleaire veiligheid en de Belgische initiatieven daarover. We hebben een duidelijke keuze gemaakt: uitstap uit of kernenergie in 2025. Is dat gemakkelijk? Neen, dat is niet gemakkelijk. Is het een ambitie? Ja, dat is een ambitie, maar wij willen duidelijk alles doen om daar ook resultaten te boeken. We hebben of ministerraad laatste weken binnen, met of steun van de deelstaten, in dit verband verbintenissen bevestigd. Wat de veiligheid betreft, staan wij permanent in contact met eleven buurlanden, ook met internationaal toezicht wat dit betreft, puts Duitsland bijvoorbeeld en tevens met andere landen. I note that some systematically try to cause anxiety, panic and anxiety. We assume our responsibilities by entrusting independent bodies responsibility for nuclear control. Mr. Lamberts, this government that you do not like — and I understand it — is the government that has developed interconnections with neighbouring countries, investment, and an offshore wind farm, which is developing more and more. On the other hand, Belgium is the second country after France to have implemented green bonds: €5 billion mobilized from Belgium for the energy transition. Finally, I would like to address a number of other topics that have been discussed, including the European budget. De Europese begroting is natuurlijk een cruciaal moment en we moeten daar zeker een duidelijke keuze maken, doen arbitration. Ik en niemand hier onderschatten hoe belangrijk het is op dat punt beslissingen te nemen. Ik heb duidelijk gezegd en ik herhaal: er is een nuttig voorstel van de Europese Commissie. Dat is a startpunt. Maar tegelijkertijd denken we ook vanuit Belgium dat we alles moeten om de middelen beter te besteden. Dat lijkt ons logisch. Maar wij zijn ook realistisch. Wij weten ook dat wij, als het nodig is, ons klassiek beleid, eleven klassieke initiatieven vanuit of Europese United moeten consolideren. Dat is ook cruciaal. Het nieuwe beleid te openen, you versterken in mogelijk te maken. De control van onze grenzen, meer steun voor eleven veiligheid, extern en ook intern. Meer steun ook voor onderzoek, meer steun voor digitalisering, daar liggen cruciale uitdagingen. Daarom zijn wij zoals altijd bereid om en een onderhandeling te stappen met realism. Zeker met realism, maar ook met de ambitie om de Europese United met de national staten echt in staat te stellen de juiste antwoorden met resultaten voor eleven medeburgers te bieden. That is the way in which we are going to engage in this negotiation. Finally, I hear lessons in taxation from Mr Lamberts. Thank you for the advice you give me on this subject. Ik ben daar ook zeer duidelijk geweest. Tax is in eleven ogen in eerste instantie een nationale bevoegdheid. Moeten wij meer samenwerken? Ja, maar ik betreur, mijnheer Lamberts,... I regret, Mr Lamberts, when we did the corporate tax reform to increase tax to 25% and even 20% for SMEs, we did not have the support of your political party in the Belgian Parliament. Therefore, there is indeed a speech here and acts there that are of a different nature. Unlike you, we are convinced that taxation is not an instrument that serves to punish or punish, but an instrument that serves to support the economic development, prosperity and purchasing power of those who work or want to work. Andere belangrijke punten. Mevrouw Van Brempt, ik hoor ook een gerucht, namelijk dat Belgium de belasting op fiscale of international transacties zou blokkeren. Een gerucht. Een gerucht! Idioot, idioot, surrealistisch! We zijn niet alleen niet in staat om zo'n dossier te blokkeren en — Jean-Claude Juncker is getuige — ik heb een paar maanden geleden dit dossier tijdens de Europese Raad aan de orde gesteld. In wat heb ik vastgesteld? Dat vele landen, omdat de brexit een realiteit geworden is, voorzichtiger zijn geworden. Dat is of realiteit! I think that, in the long term, we will have to move towards taxation of international transactions. Probably first in a European framework, but we will have to do so. Not in the way you want, which aims to punish, guilt and hence damage the real economy. I do not want to degrade the real economy, but I know you are not very concerned about it. (Strong reaction from Mr Lamberts off microphone) You are not very concerned, Mr Philippe Nigel Farage, you are slipping into populism and extremism. I think it is not worthy of training such as yours in Europe. Finally, I certainly want to thank Nigel Farage for his good advice on the future of Belgium. I am delighted to hear Nigel Farage's good advice on Belgium's future. He has dealt with Britain's future with Brexit and we can see where the situation in Britain is today. From brexit is natuurlijk en belangrijke uitdaging voor de 27 landen, maar ook voor de toekomst van het Verenigd Koninkrijk. Wat is situatie? Ik ben mij er natuurlijk van bewust dat Belgium en van de landen in Europa is die bijzonder kunnen worden getroffen ten gevolge van de brexit. Daarom willen wij een geloofwaardige onderhandeling. Daarom willen wij zeer geëngageerd zijn om een duidelijke as met het Verenigd Koninkrijk te handhaven, op economisch level maar ook voor de toekomst van eleven veiligheid. There is work carried out by Michel Barnier — it is not a simple job — with the support of the Commission and the Council, who are following this negotiation very closely. Demonstration is made: want to leave the Union club European Union has a number of consequences, a number of difficulties and we will be very mobilized in the coming months to be a committed and active partner in order to find common sense in this useful negotiation. It seems to me that Parliament will also be very committed to this extremely important subject. Mr Juncker, a quick word on Belgian citizenship. I am delighted that there is such an attractiveness for Belgian citizenship, that British citizens are also seeking to join our country in which they often live for a long time. What is the situation, very simply? There is currently — it is the rule of law, the independence of the judiciary — contradictory jurisprudence in Belgium on this subject. The government is considering from a legal point of view the possibilities on a subject that I understand is important to a number of people who have long been present in this country. These are some of the things I wanted to mention. You understood that. Thank you for this lively, intense debate. Be convinced in any case, with the nuance, but also with all the strength of commitment, that Belgium has the ambition to remain in the cockpit of a project in which we believe with great fervour because indeed, as was rightly said by Guy Verhofstadt, history has shown that this is the path of cooperation, peace , dialogue, the gathering of forces, which is the path to guaranteeing freedom, democracy and the rule of law, to which, I repeat, stand as in our eyes.

name: Presidente. –
text: The debate is certainly lively and we show that in this Parliament we are debating the issues that affect our fellow citizens. The aim is to reduce the distance between institutions and citizens more and more, and seeing the stands full of public only fill us with joy. I greet all the citizens of Europe who listen to this debate because, I repeat, our aim is to try to solve the problems of Europeans.

name: Ivo Belet (PPE).
text: Mr President, Prime Minister, I think you have put the right priorities forward. You spoke of a strong European economy investing. You have referred to fair taxes, including on Internet giants, the fight against social dumping and, therefore, security. You say that we as the European Union must achieve results in order to regain people's trust. I think that's the right summary. That security, Prime Minister. You have also referred to European defence. Mr Juncker said yesterday that EUR 20 billion has been provided for in this multiannual budget to develop European defence. Now, that is very much in line with the Franco-German project recently launched to strengthen this European defence and to build a European fighter plane together. I would like you to confirm here that Belgium is joining this European project. To sum up, we only have one minute, Prime Minister: stay on that course. Do not be distracted by the so-called euro-realistic forces, by those euro-sceptic forces in your government. Stay on that course! I think that together we can convince people that it is good to use European funds to strengthen our borders, to regain that confidence from the people, to focus on social fair taxation and, above all, on greater security, projects involving a European surplus-value. I think we can convince people that this is good for everyone and that it adds value to all people in the European Union.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D).
text: — Mr President, Prime Minister, Belgium is really a tax haven for big fortunes and multinationals who pay, as you said, at least 25%. In fact, they pay a lot less with your tax rulings. This is a hell for workers who pay an average of 42.8% on their income. Belgium is also one of the countries in the Council which does everything possible to keep the current system of tax dumping, which makes competition unfair in the European internal market and prevents tax harmonisation, which is crucial for combating money laundering and terrorist financing, tax evasion, fraud, etc. Does the government oppose the VAT reform proposed by the Commission a year ago, which would be crucial to preventing EUR 50 billion from continuing to benefit from fraud, for the benefit of criminal organisations, including terrorists, and which could lead to an increase in the own resources of the European Union and the Member States? Why does your government oppose CCCTB on digital industries, polluting industries and financial transactions?

name: Marek Jurek (ECR).
text: — Thank you Prime Minister for your presence with us and especially for the Belgian hospitality because, working in Belgium, we spend half the time here in Brussels. I am referring to the European problem, not just the problem of the European Union, but of Europe as a whole. Five days ago, you had a very interesting stay in Moscow during which you had an intimate conversation in Novo-Ogaryovo with President Vladimir Putin. You proposed rethinking the economic relations between the European Union and Russia, especially between Belgium and Russia. At the end of your trip, during a conference at a high school of commerce, you advocated, citing Machiavelli, the idea of peace through trade. Do you not think that this statement turns to the farce our policy of sanctions and especially solidarity with the countries of Central Europe, which are now worried about Russia's aggressive policy?

name: Gérard Deprez (ALDE).
text: — Mr President, Prime Minister, you came to us to talk about Europe, you did it and you did it well. On the other hand, some of our colleagues, Mr Annemans and even Mr Lamberts have used their speaking time as the backyard of the Belgian Parliament. It's a real diversion! Mr Lamberts in particular spent his time in front of our House dirty your policy in Belgium. I say to Mr Lamberts, it is ugly. It's ugly what you did. Mr Prime Minister, I have noted your caution with regard to the future financing of the European Union. You acknowledge that there are sectors in which we must maintain a level of expenditure of traditional cohesion policies, the CAP. You agreed with the objectives of additional funding of the new policies and you say “we must be very sparing with regard to budgetary contributions”. So, Prime Minister, I will make you a suggestion. The European Parliament has adopted a report proposing agreement between the Council, the European Parliament and the Commission on new own resources which will ultimately reduce national contributions. Can you tell us if you will help us in that sense?

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE).
text: — The future of the European Union is unthinkable without strong and competitive agriculture. Unfortunately, the unequal direct payments applied to the different countries of the European Union not only distort the single market, but also create a class of second-class farmers. I will say openly — thousands and thousands of economically active people in Lithuania are condemned to be uncompetitive, feel inferiority, second-class citizens of the European Union. Will Belgium support the demand of Lithuania and other Eastern and Central European countries to end the discrimination against farmers and finally equalise direct payments?

name: Peter Lundgren (EFDD).
text: - Mr President! 40 billion Swedish kroner! That's what Sweden pays this year in membership fee. That's 5,400 Swedish kroner per taxpayer per year. We pay net 27 billion Swedish kroner to the EU. Now one wants to raise this amount. You want to raise it by 40 per cent. So, it is 21 billion that we want to increase our membership fee by. That means every taxpayer in Sweden pays 8,200 Swedish kronor a year. Then there is an expected increase that will be added, if and when Albania, Macedonia, Montenegro and Serbia become net contributors. Power is constantly displaced from Sweden, from Stockholm, from Sweden's parliament to Brussels. Monetary Union shall be pursued, common migration and asylum, common defence, and all legislation initiated by the Commission whose officials are not democratically elected.
