The EU is like a train that, without brakes, rushes through the night ever faster. Despite all the signals flashing red, you have learned nothing. The crash is inevitably approaching.

name: Marc Tarabella (S&D).
text: — Mr Prime Minister, you are a convinced European, no one doubts it, but this is not reflected in the light of certain statements you make or the positions of your Government on European matters. According to your statement, you do not want to consider any increase in the national contribution. Guy Verhofstadt said, we are at a crossroads, there are projects that Europe should take care of. An ambitious Europe requires additional resources. Mr. Macron raised the issue 15 days ago. But there is also your Minister of Finance — it has been said — who behind the scenes is blocking the application of the financial transaction tax, a project that we are in the majority to want. And then what about European legislation against tax evasion which in Belgium has been amputated, emptied of their meaning, and I quote the European Commission in this regard, which describes Belgium as “one of the states in Europe that most adversely affects fairness, prevents fair competition and increases the burden on taxpayers the most”. It is not me who says so, it is the European Commission. Mr Prime Minister, while the ship Europe is taking water from all sides, when the Council is a bit of a machine that overtakes at European level, what major projects can you support to revive the European momentum in favour of citizens?

name: Henna Virkkunen (PPE).
text: — Mr President, Prime Minister, it is very valuable that you are here to consider the future of Europe together with the European Parliament. I agree that when we consider what Europe's future is based on, it must be based on European values. It is important that we defend democracy, freedom, democracy, rule of law. It is particularly important today when we are celebrating International Press Freedom Day. We know that a free, independent, pluralistic press and media are an important bedrock of democracy that we must defend across Europe. Yesterday the Commission submitted its own proposal for a future European financial framework. I hope that we will also receive strong support from Belgium to continue investment in young people and in the future of young people. It is a base on which Europe will prosper in the future. It is great that the Commission proposed doubling the Erasmus exchange programme. We know how important it is for young people in Europe to have an opportunity to get to know other countries. Similarly, investment in research, education and innovation must continue.

name: Ramón Jáuregui Atondo (S&D).
text: Mr President, Prime Minister, speaking of security, it has been almost 15 years since European cities have been experiencing terrorist attacks which you remember very well. In Brussels, Madrid, Paris, etc. Terrorist actions always come from the same structure, from the same organization, from the same ideology. And it makes a long way to think that this security risk for European citizens is a risk that remains alive and will last a long time. My question, Mr Prime Minister, is: knowing what is the police reaction to this insecurity, do you not think that, speaking of the future of Europe, the time has come to talk also about anti-terrorist police coordination? Do you not think that, speaking of the future of Europe and security for citizens, there is a need for the creation of a European unit for counter-terrorism analysis and intelligence? Do you not think it is appropriate to talk about a European anti-terrorist police force?

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Mr Prime Minister of Belgium, Mr Michel, you referred to European defence and NATO, but NATO is washing its hands in relation to Turkey's aggression and threats against Greece and Cyprus. In addition, so far no European army has been set up, which could possibly support Greece against Turkey's threats. I would therefore like to ask you, Prime Minister of Belgium, whether Belgium, as a state, is prepared to conclude with Greece a defence cooperation agreement with a military assistance clause in the event of an attack by Turkey against Greece, a pact guaranteeing the Greek borders, which is also European, a pact that will be concluded immediately, as Erdogan intensifies his threats against Greece and continues the illegal detention of our two soldiers, for whom I appeal, Prime Minister, to declare here in the European Parliament the your support for the immediate release of our two soldiers from Turkish prisons.

name: Charles Michel
text: Prime Minister of Belgium. — (FR) Mr President, some reactions to the inquiries. Indeed, I agree with Ivo Belet's point of view, which aims to combine European determination with a sense of pragmatism and a sense of realism, which must be translated in particular in the context of defence. I can't come back. I have already spoken on the question of taxation, and there have been further inquiries on the subject. We have implemented substantial tax reforms in my country with a view to reducing the tax burden substantially, first on low and average wages. In my country, in three years, low and average wages have been granted through tax reform, in fact, an additional thirteenth month. It was a fairness approach. At the same time, as I said, we are reforming corporate taxes to lower the rate to 25 and 20% to reduce the number of tax niches that existed, Mr Tarabella, when your party ran the Belgian government. We have put ourselves in order in taxation, with the support of parliament. As far as the European budget is concerned, Mr Tarabella, I want to be precise. Don't misinterpret my remarks. I did not say that we do not want to contribute more, I say that there are two topics in any budget debate. This also applies to the European debate. What are the choices in terms of envelope and amount and how are they used? How are they affected? How do we define priorities? These are the two issues that we need to look at in parallel. What are the arbitrations that can be made, it seems to me. An important issue was Russia. She was referring to a comment I made when quoting Machiavelli. It's true. Machiavelli, peace through trade. I do believe that there is some truth in this ambition. I have had the opportunity, on several occasions, in the European Council to defend my reasoning on Russia. I am of total solidarity with the territorial integrity of Ukraine. I am of total solidarity for the implementation of the Minsk agreements. There is no shadow of doubt about this. My country is very supportive of our military, especially, and our fighter planes who help secure airspace at the borders with Russia, but at the same time, I do not think that sanctions, in general, are an end in themselves. Sanctions are an instrument, an instrument for enabling and attempting political dialogue. It is in this spirit, to improve understanding, to try to see how one can manage disputes, to find solutions with Russia. I am not naive, I see a number of geopolitical and geostrategic interests and ambitions. We Europeans have at least two topics with Russia. How to secure and stabilise borders is Europe-Russia? How to generate, in the long term, economic development and trade, peace through trade? Another topic concerns the situation in southern Europe and Russia's geopolitical role in regions of the world that may, perhaps even dramatically, affect the future of Europe. In Syria, we saw him. In Libya, too. There is probably too little talk about Libya, in my view. I believe that on these subjects, indeed, we must try to open channels of dialogue without naivety, with determination, to defend our values, but also to try to make progress on these issues. One more word about Greece and relations with Turkey. At the European Council, solidarity with Greece has been repeatedly affirmed. This was expressed in conclusions as well. A word about terrorism. The people of Europe have been struck, and I am well placed as Belgian Prime Minister to tell you about it, by this tragedy of terrorism. The first attacks began with the Jewish Museum in Brussels, in the heart of Brussels. Then a wave started. It is our values of the rule of law, democracy and freedom that are at stake. Therefore, yes, to continuously strengthen cooperation between the security services. How is this possible? By having more automatic exchange of information and not just on a bilateral basis as is often the case today. This is something extremely important to me and I will be on the side of those who want to combine this reinforcement of the material, technological and legal means for our security services, but also every time ensuring full respect for the fundamental values of human rights and the right to privacy. Indeed, we must concentrate our efforts to raise the level of security because raising the level of security is really guaranteeing the freedom of European citizens.

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE)
text: — Dear Prime Minister, thank you for the open and inspiring speech. You reminded us that the European idea is more than political pragmatism, geostrategy, shared defense and occasionally covering individual aggressiveness. Thank you for your reflections on European culture, science and youth. Also thank you for the hospitality that Belgium has offered to some Catalan leaders. No one in Europe should be in fear, let alone in prison, because of their ideas. Europe must be a place of dialogue, freedom, humanism, peace and creativity, but not, never and nowhere, threats and repression.

name: Ana Miranda (Verts/ALE).
text: — Mr President, Prime Minister, I am a Galician in the European Parliament. Galicia is very attached to Belgium for immigration and I am also very attached to it because my daughter was born in Brussels. Former MEP Maurits Coppieters said a very transcendental phrase for the future of Europe: “the battle of sovereignty is also solidarity between the peoples of Europe”. The European elections will take place on 26 May 2019. You talked about a culture respectful of different identities and, in order to respect identities, Belgium sent a very strong signal when the CETA Treaty was discussed with Canada. We are debating in the Council on the electoral threshold and the ceiling. I wanted to thank you for Belgium's position, but I would like to know what its final position will be. Will we have the electoral ceiling for elections so that small political parties representing diversity are also present in the next legislature?

name: Jiří Payne (EFDD).
text: — Mr President, Prime Minister, the Treaty of Lisbon states in Article 17 that a member of the Commission must be selected according to the criterion of Europeanism. This means that in the Czech Republic, for example, 68% of citizens can never have their interests represented in the Commission. And they are discriminated against based on their political beliefs. In doing so, the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union says in Article 22 that any discrimination on the basis of political sentiment is prohibited. You said, Prime Minister, that you don't want to change the Treaties. But I believe that the Lisbon Treaty, which organises discrimination, must be abolished and we must offer citizens a better alternative for cooperation in Europe.

name: Maria Arena (S&D).
text: — Mr President, Prime Minister, I have no doubt about your economic liberalism. And when it comes to trade, I think you should assume it completely because saying that today, through trade agreements, you protect your farmers is still something quite paradoxical. As we know today, the current agreements do not save farmers or the climate. Tell me how the importation of thousands of tonnes of Canadian or Mexican beef and pork will not affect the production of European farmers? I think the only way to advance this cause of social and environmental protection is to have “sustainable development” chapters with sanctions in trade agreements. So what is Belgium's position so that you can finally reconcile your economic liberalism with your clear desire to protect both social and environmental norms, and at the same time your farmers.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: “Prime Minister, I listened carefully to you. I appreciate your commitment, your enthusiasm and share your ideas for prosperity, security and values. But let me ask you a few questions. Why do you want to open legal routes for migrants? Do you think that millions of people living in very difficult conditions can be transferred instead of bringing peace and prosperity to their home countries? How do you want to strengthen the competitiveness of European companies if we complicate the free market with the new Posting of Workers Directive? In any case, we follow the same line, as you hope a safe and prosperous future for our children.

name: Κώστας Μαυρίδης (S&D).
text: Prime Minister, you started your first speech by saying that the collective good we all enjoy here in the European Union is peace and the pursuit of prosperity. We all agree and let us talk a little bit about the future of Europe. I think we don't need to discover any other ideal. We have our ideals and are listed as Europe in the “Rule of Law”, in the rule of law. We have the answers. We have the answer on the banking union: deposit guarantee at a pan-European level. We have the answer to Erdogan's Turkey: sanctions. And if you don't believe in sanctions, you give us the answer. Well, we're seeing the result of Mr. Juncker's gifts. As we speak today, he is sending back the persecuted refugees to blackmail us. So tell us an effective policy if you do not believe in sanctions.

name: Helga Stevens (ECR).
text: Mr President, Prime Minister, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you for your vision of the future of the European Union. Now, what is striking, not only with you, but also with your colleague President Macron, is that there is little talk about people with disabilities. In the EU, they represent a very large group of 80 million people. A forgotten group, too. Do they also count in the Europe of the future? Do we also see those people as full citizens of Europe who can also contribute to the Europe of the future? I would like to know this from you, and we must not forget that all European countries have ratified the UN Convention on Persons with Disabilities. The European Union has also helped to ratify this. Nevertheless, we are still waiting for a general non-discrimination directive. For years we have been waiting for a European accessibility law to be strengthened. Where is this respect for sign languages in the European Union? That is our language, the language of deaf people in Europe. Deaf people feel unrecognized. They feel that Europe does not pay attention to them. I would also like to hear a reaction to these various elements. We can deaf people and show people with disabilities in general that Europe can also help them. When we look at the United States, we have a great backlog to catch up. We should be more ambitious so that people with disabilities can really count and be included in the Europe of the future.

name: Charles Goerens (ALDE).
text: — Mr President, Mr Louis Michel has already accustomed us to fervent pleas for a humanistic, strong and generous Europe. We can see after hearing you, Prime Minister, and through this double commitment, that Europe is well in your genes. We need political actors of this kind because Europe is under threat. The worst threat at present, however, is the fact that several Member States deviate from the fundamental values of the Union, do not apply or no longer apply certain aspects of European law. How, from your point of view, could it be remedied?

name: Jordi Solé (Verts/ALE).
text: — Mr Prime Minister, thank you for having devoted much of your speech to talking to us about fundamental values and for reminding us of the tenacity our democracies demand from us. It is important to stress that without respect for European values, there is no European project worth the trouble. It is important to stress this at a time when some Member States are behaving in a worrying way, for example Spain, where Catalan politicians have been imprisoned for allowing citizens to vote, yes, to vote. In any case, I would like to hear your opinion on what we call the rule of law conditionality, a mechanism which the European Commission has incorporated into its proposal for a multiannual financial framework to fund Community funds. In my view, it would be a pity if this mechanism applies only to the rule of law and not to other aspects of democracy, human rights or corruption.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D).
text: — Mr. President, Mr. Prime Minister, we in Romania have a proverb saying that divide, we cannot do much, together, united, we can do a lot. And I am referring here to your policy, unfortunately similar to that of President Macron, on a multi-speed Europe. We need, Prime Minister, a united and developed Europe. Developed to the East, as it is to the West. Only together will we be able to make a strong, respected European Union a global player who plays an important role in this world. At the same time, yesterday, the European Commission presented us with a massive declining budget for agricultural policy and cohesion policy. I want to tell you that cohesion policy is a symbolic policy, key, essential for European construction. This policy must continue, we must not increase the cleavage and differences between Western Europe and Central and Eastern Europe. On the contrary, all of us, the citizens of Central and Eastern Europe, when we joined the European Union, considered and believe that we must have the same level of development, the same rights and the same future, and I call on you, Prime Minister, to support a common European policy.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Mr Prime Minister, I was listening very carefully to your introductory speech and I realised during your speech that you are real true European as you said. Since this is a debate on the future of Europe, you also said that you are against a two-speed Europe. You mentioned Schengen, you mentioned the eurozone, but you haven't said anything about further integration of the European Union. You haven't mentioned anything about the Western Balkans or Southeast Europe. So I would like to hear from you, what is your opinion, what is your attitude – I mean you as Prime Minister and a Belgian – on widening the European Union? Do you have any standpoint on this issue?

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: — Mr President, Prime Minister, I will not speak of your speech because I greatly enjoyed it. But since there have been some contradictions, I want to ask you a few questions to clarify them. When President Juncker asked you to give citizenship to British citizens, you responded very promptly - and I appreciate you - that, of course, you need to think about the case law in your State. Then, I ask you, will you vote on that new conditionality relating to the rule of law in the Council? And secondly, will you vote on the cutting of funds to cohesion and the common agricultural policy? And, Prime Minister, the last question, I feel safer in my country, Romania - which unfortunately is not in Schengen - than in your country, where you know what happened. Will you vote for Romania's entry into Schengen?

name: Hilde Vautmans (ALDE).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, Prime Minister, thank you for your very strong and pro-European speech. It is such leaders that we should see more often here in Europe. Today I am a proud Fleming, a proud Belgian, a committed European and, above all, a convinced liberal. Because I think you have put the right emphasis: prosperity, economy, security, migration and, of course, our European values and standards. There is one point, Prime Minister, for which I would like to draw your attention today. We believe that we need to do more to tackle migration here in Europe. The citizens of Europe are asking for that too. I published a book last week about 10 000 unaccompanied minor asylum seekers missing in Europe, including in our country. I would therefore like to ask for your support. We are about to put a resolution to the vote here in this House. Defend decisions at the European Council to tackle smugglers harder and protect children in migration. Thank you, Prime Minister.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D).
text: Mr President, Prime Minister Michel, although we listened to you with great interest, we have not heard you a word about a European pillar in which Belgium once stood at the forefront: the area of freedom, justice and security and active judicial cooperation between Member States — based on the European mandate — of mutual trust and mutual recognition, judicial decisions, in order to avoid impunity on the basis of border crossing or on the complexity and heterogeneity of criminal legislation. In the area of freedom we need each other because — as the legendary Belgian Prime Minister Paul-Henri Spaak said — it is not true that the European Union is made up of large countries and small countries, we are all small to meet the great challenges of globalisation, only some know it and others do not yet.

name: Pascal Arimont (PPE).
text: — Monsieur le Président, Monsieur le Premier Ministre, je Suis Fier d'être Européen. Ik ben Fier Belg te Zjin. But I am also proud to be a German-speaking East Belgian. All of this works at the same time, even if this did not seem to be the case today. This is also due to Europe's great idea and its values. Belgium has been involved in Europe for 70 years. Perhaps Europe can also learn from Belgium. From this small, very complicated, but always amiable state. When nothing worked out, a Belgian came up with an idea, and it worked afterwards. However, we must rebuild the House of Europe, and the people must feel at home in Europe. This means that we must continue to develop this house; we must make it resistant to wind and weather. Belgium must make its contribution to this, and for this you, Prime Minister, must be very courageous: you must be the architect of this new Europe. I would like to quote a person here who does not come from politics, but from soccer, Liverpool FC's coach. After all, last week he said very well: 'The EU is not perfect, but it is the best idea we have ever had. 'History has shown that we can solve problems if we stick together. If we diverge, we will fight each other, and not once in history has division succeeded. This applies to Belgium as well as Europe. Soyez donc Courageux, Monsieur le Premier Ministre, be the architect of this new Europe where we all feel at home!

name: Mercedes Bresso (S&D).
text: — Mr President, Prime Minister, thank you for this pro-European speech. I'd like to ask you a question anyway. You talked about using the potential of Lisbon. I obviously agree because I was the co-rapporteur for the report on the Lisbon potential, but there is still a problem of democracy in the European Union. Do you not think that if we want to make full use of the Lisbon Treaty, we must use the bridge clause and reach a majority vote in the Council? Because this is the cause of Europe's failure to function and the criticism made by our citizens: Europe can never decide, it is slow, it cannot be on the ball, to speak in terms borrowed from football. That's the question. So, either we change the Treaties and we really democratize Europe by showing real commitment, or we do not, but at least use the Treaty of Lisbon fully, through the bridge clause, to achieve a true democratic system in Europe.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Mr President, the discussions and debates here with the Prime Minister started by my own Prime Minister in January – Leo Varadkar – have been very impressive and worthwhile and Mr Michel today is equally impressive, knowledgeable and competent and up-front. So two points I want to make one. One, I would ask him to do everything he can to increase the budget for the European Union. This is where the added value is. My second question is, does he see a smooth Brexit and if not, what are the consequences for Belgium? The other point made by my colleague Ms Šuica is expansion. How quick does he see expansion in the European Union, especially in relation to the Western Balkans?

name: Μαρία Σπυράκη (PPE).
text: Mr Prime Minister of Belgium, you represent a country in the North, I represent a country in the South, but we live in the same house and we can only welcome in Greece the tripling of the funds for asylum and border guarding. At the same time, however, it is essential that we proceed immediately to a uniform asylum system in the European Union. At the same time, it is necessary to strengthen the protection of European borders in practice, and here I would like to point out that it is necessary to make the return of the two Greek soldiers who are currently illegally detained in Edirne, Turkey, a European priority. In this way we will prove that we really live in the same house and that we do share the same values.

name: Charles Michel
text: Prime Minister of Belgium. — (FR) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, several important points have been raised again, and I will react to some of them. An important point is, of course, the subject of free trade, freedom of trade. Machiavelli was quoted earlier. I believe deeply in the virtues of free trade, provided there is reciprocity, provided that there are social and environmental standards. Maria Arena is well aware that many free trade agreements are based on negotiating mandates given sometimes many years ago, which do not take into account certain positive developments necessary in terms of social and environmental standards. It is based on this approach that I have entered Belgium's position. It is in this approach that I supported, as far as I am concerned — unlike you — CETA, and it is in this approach, very consistently and consistently, that I want to defend the situation of farmers by defending reciprocity, by not accepting, for example in the case of Mercosur — a negotiating mandate that goes far back in the past — that farmers be a sort of adjustment variable in negotiation. This is a first point. I will also address another extremely important subject that has been mentioned — and which I did not mention in my introductory remarks — namely the situation in the Western Balkans. I was indeed in the Western Balkans a few days ago to meet my Serbian, Albanian counterparts and I am one of those who believe that Europe must be much more engaged, much more mobilized to help stabilise this region. I think Europe underestimates how fundamental this subject is, and I ask myself a question: should we not consider the appointment of a special envoy of the European Union with a real mediation capacity in order — as we do, in some way, with Michel Barnier in the case of Brexit — to have a full-time personality with authority, the support and legitimacy needed to make a real contribution to stabilizing and securing the region. It is in this hypothesis that we can effectively exploit the processes of relationship between the European Union and that region, in an attempt to make progress towards our own stability and security. Several questions were also asked about convergence, on cohesion. I would like to confirm that the challenge is to develop a capacity for economic and social convergence at European level, which I welcome. Ik verheug mij over de initiatieven van de Europese Commissie, de rol van Jean-Claude Juncker en van de eurocommissaris om naar en sokkel voor de sociale rechten te streven. Dat is een eerste belangrijke stap die een paar maanden geleden in Gothenburg is gerealiseerd. Nude, het is de verantwoordelijkheid van de landen om, met de steun van de Europese Commissie, hierin bijkomende vooruitgang te boeken, voor meer samenwerking te zorgen en meer resultaten en meer convergentie te verwezenlijken. Dat moet ook in mijn ogen en belangrijke doelstelling zijn. Mevrouw Vautmans, natuurlijk ben ik het met a ten aanzien van een sterker Europees commitment. Ik ken ook uw sterk persoonlijk Europees commitment. U heeft en belangrijk punt gemaakt. Ik onderschat dat niet. We hebben in Belgium initiatieven ondernomen voor niet-begeleide minderjarigen met steun van de deelstaten die op dit gebied bevoegd zijn. Maar ik ben echt bereid om mij daarvoor nog meer te engeren. Dat is inderdaad en belangrijke uitdaging for toekomst. Bridges were made with police and security cooperation. I also link with the Schengen area. I care about the Schengen area. I think this is an extremely important issue, and it is because I care about the Schengen area that I believe that we must be able to guarantee security in order to guarantee free movement, to make progress in terms of border protection and to implement an orderly migration policy, as I have said, in the field of migration. An important remark was made about the knowledge society. Lisbon. I am therefore, I was among the first to advocate for multi-speed Europe. I does believe that we must mobilize everything to ensure that we can move forward with those who wish to do so, without being blocked by a few who either want not to move forward or take more time to move forward. This is the sense of my reasoning, which I hope was able to detail on paper in speed. Finally, Mr President, I thank you for this debate and for this exchange, which reflect the vitality of what the European model does: the rule of law, democracy, the peaceful confrontation of ideas with mutual respect. As Voltaire said, I do not necessarily share your conviction, but I will fight for you to have the freedom to express it. I would also like to commend the press that is following our work on this important day of press freedom. Even in Europe, ensuring daily press freedom is a challenge that must mobilise us all. Earlier I mentioned the qualities of those who have been at the heart of the progress towards a concrete, tangible European project, peace, prosperity, stability and freedoms. Courage, optimism and confidence, this is undoubtedly the recipe for moving in the right direction. Forward Europe!

name: Le Président. –
text: Thank you for your words. I share what you say about the press. As a former journalist, I support and defend press freedom. Today there will be a ceremony in memory of Daphne Caruana Galizia, the Maltese journalist who was killed in an attack a few months ago. Parliament will always support freedom of the press. Mr Prime Minister, we had a debate, a real debate on the future of Europe, a lively debate, of course, but a real debate. This is a positive message that we are sending to our fellow citizens, to the citizens who are in the forums and who have listened to this debate. As I said, more than 40 members have spoken and asked questions. I think that this way of operation is positive and helps very much relations between the European Parliament, the Commission, the Council and governments. We must all work together to defend the rights of our fellow citizens. A big thank you, Prime Minister, I greet you and then we will move forward. Mrs Gomes is your question related to what I have just said? What is it? Tell me.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D).
text: — Mr President, you talked about paying tribute to the memory of Mrs Daphne Caruana Galizia, but we must also recall the Slovak journalist, Ján Kuciak, and his partner who were also murdered for similar reasons. I would like to express my concern at this time by a letter we have received from Europol, which sets out the limitations on investigations and any collaboration with the authorities in these investigations. This is a case we need to deal with.

name: Le Président. –
text: Of course, ma'am, but I said a ceremony will be held today for Daphne Caruana Galizia. As a former journalist, I am also very well informed of what happened. For Daphne but also for this Irish journalist killed a few years ago, those killed in Slovakia and all the others. Many thanks to all of you, thank you again to the Prime Minister, to the European Commission and to all the Members who participated in this debate, as well as to all the citizens who are here listening to us. Thank you. We are working for you. Written declarations (article 162)

name: Krystyna Łybacka (S&D)
text: in writing. — I draw the attention of the Prime Minister to the importance of high quality and inclusive education in building Europe's future, both economically and socially. In the context of the creation of a European education area, we must set ambitious goals that will contribute to the development of a knowledge-based Europe, enhancing competitiveness, social cohesion and opportunities for lifelong learning. I also emphasise the role of educational mobility for students, academics and administrative staff as crucial for the formation of new skills and attitudes, the deepening of cross-cultural understanding and the strengthening of European unity. In this context, it is important both to guarantee equal opportunities for all under the new Erasmus+ programme and to integrate mobility into educational programmes. More support of teaching staff is also key, as an essential pillar for student and student success and the development of quality education. I strongly support and encourage the establishment of a European teaching and learning academy to promote the cooperation of teachers, improve the quality of teaching and supporting the professional development of teachers.

name: Ivan Štefanec (PPE)
text: in writing. - Charles Michel has expressed his idea of a strong Europe, which works especially where it can add real value. I agree that we need more cooperation, especially in areas that bring concrete benefit to our citizens. One of these areas is definitely the common digital market, mentioned by the Prime Minister. I am of the opinion that the creation of a common European digital market is the only right way to move this subject forward. Therefore, after the removal of roaming, it is necessary to remove geoblocking as soon as possible and improve the conditions not only for the free movement of information, but also for electronic commerce. I am extremely pleased that, in his speech, the Prime Minister also stressed the necessity of preserving European values. New technologies bring many benefits to our everyday lives, but the spread of radical ideas with the help of social media threatens democracy. We must therefore bear in mind that the future of Europe will also be about protecting our fundamental values.

name: Maria Grapini (S&D).
text: — Madam President, under the Rules of Procedure I would like to inform you that, at the debate with the Belgian Prime Minister, a colleague addressed the Prime Minister with the following phrase: 'You are the girl in the class who raises her hand and never makes history'. I think it is discrimination, girls make history, women make history, and it is not normal to discriminate in the European Parliament.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The term itself is quite unsuitable regardless of the sex of the person, Madam.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The next item is Voting Time. (For the results of the votes and other details concerning them: see Minutes)

name: La Présidente. –
text: This closes Voting Time.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: - Madam President, this report on fraud to the detriment of the European Union's financial instruments shows quite tough figures. So there are about twenty thousand irregularities a year that fall within OLAF's competence. These are huge sums of money, and as a Hungarian, who has already become accustomed to being in a permanent defensive position, it automatically occurred to me that if there are such huge numbers here, and the report clearly describes that all countries are involved, why with Hungary they are constantly dealing with this issue, corruption, etcetera. Then it occurred to me that it would be nice if we did not have to defend ourselves all the time, but really start to deal with our own affairs and correct the mistakes that are undoubtedly in my country, for example, using European Union instruments. It would be time for this war to end, and we could finally deal with things like this.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: — Madam President, how is European citizens' money lost or stolen? In 2015, the losses caused by the difference between theoretical and real revenues from VAT receipts, plus VAT fraud, in the Union amounted to around EUR 160 billion. To the Cohesion Fund alone, which is very important for the development of all Member States and regions, reported fraud increased to EUR 480 million in 2016. We need to know what pockets this money came into, which had to balance the development of the Member States. Fraud and corruption do not fight with slogans or speeches, but with targeted measures and cross-border cooperation. I demand: (1) the rapid establishment of the European Public Prosecutor; (2) cross-checking of accounting records between Member States; (3) the publication of an annual report by the Commission on the use of Union funds and the EIB and EBRD money transfers to tax havens.

name: Bogdan Andrzej Zdrojewski (PPE).
text: — We are improving the protection of the European Union's financial interests and this is, without doubt, the most valuable consideration in this matter. Whereas, unfortunately, we do so firstly, very slowly and secondly, unfortunately inconsistently. I do not command the data that is presented in the report itself. It seems to me that they are underestimated, but without any doubt we must ensure that the European Parliament, and the European institutions, respond more efficiently and quickly to various irregularities. We listed them yesterday: exchanging tobacco trade, exchanging fakes from China, also exchanging mis-taxed digital market, as well as mistakes in the implementation of programmes that have been mentioned many times in this room: common agricultural policy, cohesion policy. We need to — again I will stress — be fitter, more consistent and quicker responsive.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR).
text: — Dear Madam President, honourable Members, I supported the 2016 annual report on the protection of the financial interests of the European Union because I believe that all the important aspects have been described, the issues of additional accountability requested are highlighted. Mr Bernio's report states that it is necessary to build a European Public Prosecutor's Office, which has its own resources to detect abuse and fraud. The report itself promotes faster and effective compilation of this Prosecutor's Office. I also draw particular attention to the Directive on the Protection of Financial Interests, which introduces minimum rights with regard to the definitions of criminal offences and sanctions in the field of fraud affecting the financial interests of the Union, which cover cross-border VAT fraud. The Directive defines corruption and sets out the types of fraudulent behaviour that should be criminalised. This is a first step towards harmonising European criminal law. The report calls on the Commission to publish an annual publicly available report on the use of European Union funds, as well as on the remittances of the European Investment Bank, the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development to Offshore Structures. I believe that these steps will contribute to more effective protection of the Union's financial interests.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: — Madam President, I supported this report, I think it is a good thing to debate in plenary here how the financial interests of the European Union are protected, but I believe that the basic decisions for the recourse of unlawful and particularly criminal activities in the defence of the financial interests of the European Union will always be up to the Member States, the law enforcement agencies in the individual Member States. We should take care that individual Member States do not underestimate this form of crime and should take care to ensure that individual law enforcement agencies in individual Member States cooperated with each other and exchanged information. That, I think, is the basis for the future to prevent European money being ripped away. I am not so convinced, unlike other colleagues, that the establishment of a new European Public Prosecutor's Office, which will only be established by some European Union states, will significantly solve this problem. But only history will show whether optimists are right, and this office will help. I am skeptical of that.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, it is certainly a positive result that the fraudulent and non-fraudulent irregularities reported in 2016 have fallen by 15%. However, the persistent gap between Member States in relation to reports carried out leads to misperception of the effectiveness of controls. It is in this area that the Commission must work more to support the level and quality of controls and the sharing of best practices in combating fraud. We need a uniform system of comparable data collection in order to even out the reporting process and ensure the quality and comparability of the data provided, but we also need a more effective cooperation between Member States, the European Prosecutor's Office, OLAF and Eurojust. To date, not all Member States have adopted national anti-fraud strategies and 50% of cases reported by OLAF are filed by national authorities also due to a failure to harmonisation of the conditions for the admissibility of tests provided by OLAF.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Madam President, this Annual Report is important to assess the level of fraud or attempted fraud that occurs in the EU over the year. I welcome it and I voted for it. The results of this Annual Report are very promising. It outlines that there was a 15% decrease in fraudulent and non-fraudulent irregularities in the EU in 2016, compared to 2015. This decrease clearly illustrates that the implementations that have been introduced are effective and they are helping to combat fraud across the EU. We welcome that. This report also includes suggestions for the protection of whistle-blowers in the EU, in ensuring they are afforded the best treatment while investigating their complaints. The Report also suggests methods that may be introduced to combat further fraud in the future. This is imperative for Ireland, and for the EU as a whole, to ensure that the euro currency and the economy are not taken advantage of through fraudulent means. We always have to be vigilant. Fraudsters are never going to go away.

name: Daniel Hannan (ECR).
text: – Madam President, why do we have all of this fraud in the EU institutions that we have just been hearing about? Is it that Brussels attracts particularly bad people? I do not think so. I mean, it attracts some bad people. Man is fallen and in every institution you will attract some people who give in to temptation, but the real problem is that there is no link between taxation, representation and expenditure. European institutions expect the bouquets when they write cheques but not the brickbats when they raise the taxes, because taxation is carried out by somebody else. That is a formula where, even with the best will in the world, you are bound to encourage a certain negligence or, as we have seen in some of the cases cited in this report, outright corruption. The solution, of course, would be to take the financial decisions more closely to the people that they affect, to devolve fiscal autonomy from an EU to a national or subnational level but, as we all know in this House, that ‘ain’t gonna happen’.

name: Stefano Maullu (PPE).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, this report gives a significantly comforting picture, on the one hand which is absolutely inadequate. A third of Italians have an empty refrigerator, a third of Italians are in a difficult condition and this European Union, which makes available an important financial instrument such as the Bank European investment, it has a duty to invest in our country more important and significantly. The overall pillar is not enough, which is explained in detail in the report; there are too few investments in infrastructure, too few investments that generate counter-cyclical conditions, which therefore allow lasting jobs to be created. I believe that this is one of the functions and objectives that the European Investment Bank has. These are objectives that are very often not achieved and which very often, instead, must be accurately justified, especially here, in the European Parliament, where we represent tens and tens of millions of inhabitants who ask exactly this: punctuality and transparency.

name: Rosa D'Amato
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the EIB's report on financial activities underlines some really important aspects, such as the need to promote activities financially sustainable or monitoring of added value, additionality and real leverage achieved with EIB funding. Then there is a reminder of assessment and transparency about certain high-risk financial instruments, to prevent the burden being discharged on small and medium-sized enterprises and citizens. In fact, I have long been pointing out the danger that financial engineering could create new speculative bubbles, the burst of which would shatter the European skeleton of micro, small and medium-sized enterprises, creating a backlash that would break down on citizens in a disruptive manner. In addition, to the harsh critical analysis expressed in the Valli report, I add my firm condemnation of EIB financing to projects supporting the fossil, or to obsolete steel mills or to mega unnecessary and harmful infrastructure. In the specific case of the TAP, the EIB has stubborn to finance it by hiding behind the gas supply screen — which is certainly not a renewable source — without taking due account of social, economic and environmental externalities and infischiating with potential risks to local people. As a matter of public money, the EIB should instead direct its support to contribute more targeted to the implementation of projects with real added value for the territories, for the environment and for sustainability, as well as the creation of quality jobs. In general, I therefore welcome the report and the consequent vote in favour of this report.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: — Madam President, in Romania, my country, the European Investment Bank financed over 126 projects by 2017 and invested over 13 billion euros. Romania ranks fifth in the Union in financing from EIB money. Among the projects financed are the modernization and expansion of the Regina Maria medical network and also the financing of the European energy corridor. However, we do not have a clear picture of the surplus-value, of the useful effect of these financing. Because no analysis has been made yet and, in addition, the operations of the Bank and those of the Romanian authorities must be very transparent for real public control. At the moment, they are not very transparent and, therefore, I demand transparency, so that we can control them. Transparency means control, accountability and so on.

name: Bogdan Andrzej Zdrojewski (PPE).
text: — The Committee on Budgets pointed out the qualitative deficiencies in this document, the CONT committee on the geographical imbalance, but these are not the only comments on this report. It is worth pointing out that the amount that was spent in 2016 is below the one that was spent in 2015, and geographical imbalance is actually a constant element of investing policy. I will point out two things that are very important: we have de facto only four fields funded by just these measures — I will remind you that is about 80 billion — and that is the environment, small economic entities, innovation and infrastructure. What is missing is primarily from creative sectors, which I point out in the report itself, as well as, above all, the resources invested in soft projects that would increase the quality of all that is related to creative industries. I point it out today for the second time.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: — Madam President, as I said in my speech yesterday, although Turkey continues its aggressive policy towards Greece, although Turkey violates the territorial waters of my country, although Turkey maintains the casus belli against Greece, the European Investment Bank nevertheless maintains its casus belli against Greece, continues to give low-interest loans to Turkey and thus finances small and medium-sized enterprises, transport, the agricultural sector and environmental projects. For 2014, 2.1 billion euros have been given in low-interest loans, for 2016 the European Investment Bank gave Turkey USD 2.3 billion in low-interest loans. This situation must stop. It is not possible to finance the Turkish economy at a time when Turkey pursues an aggressive policy against Greece, while it keeps the two Greek soldiers in prison. Turkey's funding from the European Investment Bank must be stopped.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, fáiltím roimh an tuairisc seo agus is dóigh liom gur maith an rud é go mbeadh Feisirí ar an eolas faoi chaiteachas agus imeachtaí Bhanc Infheistíochta na hEorpa, agus tríd an tuairisc seo agus tríd an díospóireacht a bhí againn aréir - agus bhí áthas orm páirt a ghlacadh ann - tagaimid ar an eolas sin. Freisin, tá ainm in airde ag EIB anois, go háirithe de bharr na dea-oibre atá á déanamh ag EIB maidir le hESI.  Reáchtáil mise ceithre nó cúig chruinniú phoiblí i mo cheantar féin.  Tháinig Cormac Murphy ó Éirinn agus ó EIB in Éirinn chuig na cruinnithe sin, agus bhí daoine an-sásta leis sin, chomh sásta sin go bhfuilim ag fáil cuireadh gach uile lá ó chathracha agus ó bhailte eile chun cruinniú mar sin, maidir leis an EIB, a reáchtáil chomh maith. Dá bhrí sin, tá jab an-mhaith á dhéanamh acu agus caithfimid a bheith bródúil astu.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Madam President, as we know, the early presidential election in Venezuela called by the internationally non—recognised National Constituent Assembly and endorsed by the National Electoral Council are now to be held on 20 May this year. In order to make the election process clear and have a successful result, it is necessary to find a compromise and reach an agreement between the two competing sides, because only their cooperation would enable a synergy to be reached and stabilise the country. As a Member of the European Parliament, I would also like to stress that only an objective assessment and an adequate and impartial view on the situation can solve the current problem, which has appeared in this state. We should not rely on our personal fellow feelings and give an advantage or preference to one side or another. We – I mean Europe – should be an example of independent representation, making objectivity the main criteria for our assessment concerning this country.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: — Madam President, we are talking repeatedly at plenary about the serious situation in Venezuela, we have debated here for the last time about the huge social and economic problems of the Venezuelan people, when socialist dictator Maduro has caused a once rich country today to suffer from a situation where people don't have medicines, they don't have basic necessities of life. At the same time, there is a huge constitutional crisis in this country, undemocratic processes, and unfortunately today we voted on the situation that is to happen on May 20, when premature presidential elections in Venezuela and now it is already obvious that those elections will not be free, they will not be democratic, that opposition candidates will not be able to get involved. So it is good that the European Parliament and with its vote today made clear that we do not recognise such elections and we call on the Venezuelan authorities to postpone the electoral process and bring it into line with principles of democratic rule of law.

name: Rosa D'Amato
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. — Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Novakov's report appears, in our view, too unambitious on the subject of the real environmental sustainability of alternatives to fossil. We would have liked at least one mention of the fact that transport is currently responsible for 32% of the total energy consumption of the European Union and that the emissions from the transport sector are responsible for 27% of all greenhouse gas emissions in the Union, thus constituting a serious environmental problem in terms of air pollution. In the rest of the report, we find several non-shareable references to the EFSI, in particular where it is defined as a tool that could serve as a platform for developing public partnerships. private transport. We welcome, in particular, paragraph 15 coming from an amendment of our own, where the Commission is asked, in the framework of the new regulation on cohesion policy after the 2020, to propose more funds for cities, so that they can submit joint bids relating to infrastructure or technologies that would contribute to the decarbonization of urban transport and the reduction of air pollution resulting from road vehicles. The fundamental awareness must be made, both in politics and civil society, that without a significant contribution from the transport sector, it will not be possible to achieve the objective of European Union of a minimum share of renewables and targets for reducing greenhouse gas emissions.

name: Lola Sánchez Caldentey (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, the Mediterranean corridor is a trans-European communication hub which, through a double freight and passenger rail network with international width, must bridge the entire Mediterranean arch, connecting cities such as Valencia and Murcia with the rest of Europe. Murcia represented a black dot in the route of this corridor, as it did not meet any of the European railway operating standards. To solve this, in 2014 he was granted European funds amounting to almost 1 million euros, that is, he obtained the money to remove the bottleneck from the layout of his corridor while passing through Murcia. At the moment we can say that not only has this black dot not been eliminated, but also with the current project a funnel of huge proportions is being generated. A single mixed width road that will be shared by passengers and freight and will also depart in two the city of Murcia. If we haven't removed the bottleneck, where did that money go? Surely, the honourable vice-president of this house, Ramón Luis Valcárcel, can help us clarify where these funds ended, because he was the highest political officer in the Murcia region from 1995 to 2014.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR).
text: — Dear Madam President, honourable Members, I supported my colleague Novakov's report because the European Union's cohesion policy is the most visible instrument for citizens for European added value. Investment through the European Union budget not only fulfils the long-term objectives, but has an impact on local communities and businesses. Investment in transport infrastructure under the thematic objective “Promoting sustainable transport and removing undercapacity sections across all key network infrastructures” are among the most tangible achievements of cohesion policy as they contribute to the elimination of differences within the European Union, as well as on the competitiveness and strengthening of the economic strength of all Member States. And this is especially important in the Balkans, where there is no connectivity, and where there are as many hours as it takes to get from Sofia to Brussels between the countries and capitals of member states.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Madam President, as I said in my speech yesterday, the European Union must strengthen Greece's effort to establish the transport equivalent, and I even asked Mrs Crețu for funding from the European Regional Development Fund. In her reply, Mrs Crețu threw the ball to the Greek government and said that the Greek government must formulate this measure because it belongs to Greece's exclusive competence. Therefore, the Tsipras government must roll up its sleeves and finally institutionalize the transport equivalent for the Aegean islands, in order to relieve all the islands, especially the Aegean islands, as they receive huge migratory flows. It is therefore the responsibility of the Greek side and must establish the transport equivalent here and now.

name: Morten Messerschmidt (ECR).
text: Madam. President! We voted against this report because cohesion policy, which sounds very good - like something that can unite us all together - in reality seems to be a word or concept rather than it actually covers up reality. When we look at the disastrous infrastructure projects undertaken in particularly southern European countries, where one ghost airport stands empty after another, where perhaps 20 or 30 aircraft a year takes off, or the kilometres of motorways financed by the European Union, where no cars drive, or ports where no ferries attach, bike lanes where no bikes are running, etc., etc., well then it is very, very hard to spot whether cohesion policy is in reality about making the continent work, or whether it is actually more a matter of using some nice words that are going to look like the roses as covering up the thistles. We are deeply sceptical about this whole part of the EU budget, which is why we are voting no.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: — Madam President, I consider the subject of transport sustainability to be extremely serious, really serious for the development of our cities and municipalities, and it is a key theme precisely for cohesion policy. Yes, there are examples, as my speaker spoke, where these individual projects have failed, but we have hundreds and thousands of examples where European money has helped European mobility and city connectivity; and municipalities. Here we are talking about the preference for public transport and I join those who supported this report for this very reason. It is not only about decreasing exhalations and emissions just coming from public transport, but it is also about bringing true public transport preferences, this also applies to, for example, shortening transfer distances, these are so called modal nodes of transport, telematics. And in the Czech Republic, but also in other states it also joins the issue of suburbanized territories, that is, those that are in agglomeration rings, and where transport is indeed very essential for local people and for its impacts on healthy lifestyles.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Madam President, regarding bottlenecks: tell me and my constituents in Ireland South all about them – we have no shortage of them. For instance, in my own county of Kerry, if we are travelling to the big cities on either side of us – Limerick and Cork – we have bottlenecks in Balleyvourney, Macroom, Abbeyfeale, Newcastle West and Adare. This is a huge inconvenience to natives, but also to tourists, and of course is detrimental to quality of life and leads to increased emissions, which is not good. But, thankfully, help is at hand, because there are genuine plans to eliminate those bottlenecks. I think the Cohesion funding and Structural Funds are playing a big part in that, and indeed have played a big part in improving the road network in Ireland and across the European Union, and that should be recognised.  I think it is good that we hone in now on these bottlenecks right across the European Union and eliminate them for the sake of the quality of life of all people and in our fight against climate change by reducing unnecessary emissions.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: - Madam President, it is a very interesting question as to why the Western people are actually letting themselves terrorize with this whole mass migration thing on the part of the European Union, when it is clear that the vast majority of them do not want migration. One of the explanations for this is the emotional blackmail they're involved in. If you don't want migration, then you're inhuman, antihumane, and so on. A particularly strong ground for this context is the issue of migrant children. There is this notion that unaccompanied children come to Europe out of poverty, poverty, twenty thousand a year. But let's ask you a few questions. You have to imagine six-year-olds with a baby face when we talk about these kids? No, mostly 16-17-18-year-olds. Two: why does this report, or this written document, object to the need to know the exact age of these children. Whether they're 20 to 25 by chance. Here is the issue of family reunification, which they want to make mandatory. You always have to look behind things.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: — Madam President, I would like to explain why I finally abstained from the final vote on this report, which is devoted to children in the migration crisis. Children are the most vulnerable group and we need to pay attention and protection to them. Therefore, in order to be protected, they need to be registered, registered and we need their biometric data. Unfortunately, in the vote, amendments were passed that relativise the whole resolution, and that is, I think, a mistake. It is for the benefit of children to have their papers, to be protected, they need to be registered so that we know about the place of their movement. It's in their favor. Otherwise, I greatly appreciate Lord Dubs's initiative in the UK for Britain to take in 380 refugee children. I think it's a good role model for other countries.

name: Morten Messerschmidt (ECR).
text: Madam. President! I think we've all been moved and gripped by the images we've been able to see on the TV screens, of drowning children and of course adults in the Mediterranean as well. It is therefore completely incomprehensible to me how there can still be members of this Parliament who cannot realise that it can only be stopped by closing and consistently guarding the European border. Instead of helping people here to our part of the world and thus animating people smugglers and incentivising people to use people smugglers, then we need to help people in the North African countries. If the EU is to contribute something to help people on the run, then it should be by ensuring that without crossing the Mediterranean, without spending the whole fortune on traffickers, you can be helped, making camps and cities and civilised good regions in perhaps North Africa where people can live until they can return to their own countries. This is the way across the Mediterranean that is killing people. As long as it is possible to get into Europe off that path, the parliament here has a responsibility for what happens.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE).
text: — Madam President, future generations will judge us for the way we treated the most vulnerable. The European Union must therefore protect every child in its territory, including migrants and refugees. Nevertheless, I could not support this resolution because it refers to the text we adopted in this plenary in relation to the proposal for the conclusion of the Istanbul Convention. I consider this resolution controversial not only because of its content, but also because it goes beyond the powers of both the European Union and this Parliament. Violence against children must end. However, the Istanbul Convention is not the only or best instrument for achieving this objective.

name: Petras Auštrevičius (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, calling on a global ban on animal testing for the cosmetics industry by 2023 is a very important step in the ongoing battle which aims to put an end to cruel practices against animals. It is regrettable that around 80% of the world’s countries still allow, and use, testing on animals and sell products which have been tested on them. I firmly support the European Union’s commitment to lead by example through the landmark EU ban on animal testing which was implemented in 2013, and its call for similar legislation worldwide. On this occasion I salute my colleagues, who have been campaigning for this issue for many, many decades. This is an excellent example of a successful policy by European politicians. The EU ban has proved to be extremely successful. We have developed alternative testing methods for cosmetics and still remain the leader in cosmetics exports. Therefore, I am convinced that other countries can benefit from that too. Let’s end cruelty against animals together.

name: Branislav Škripek (ECR).
text: — Madam President, it is a good thing that the European Union is putting itself as a leader in the field of animal protection and banning the testing of cosmetic products on them. We live in a world where almost 80% of countries still allow animal testing and the subsequent sale of these cosmetic products. We need to push for the development of alternative methods, whether through research support, but also a ban on imports of products from third countries that do not comply with Union rules. It is interesting to look into the catechism of the Catholic Church, where it is written that God authorized man to use animals for food, clothing and agricultural purposes. However, this right is not absolute, and a person has a duty to them also be kind. It is immoral for us to inflict any unfounded suffering on animals and treat them like things. They too are God's creatures, but things have limits.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D).
text: — Madam President, the effective ban on the use of animals in tests in the cosmetic industry and the marketing of such products has been in Europe since 2013, but unfortunately nearly 80% of other countries do not have similar legislation. The marketing of such products must be strictly observed so that there is no single market situation in which European producers have more difficult conditions to produce or displace the products. The recently released information on the inhumane treatment of animals during transport from Australia is just a small example of how global trade lacks rules to put European producers on the same footing as those from third countries. The European Commission must look very carefully at all such bad practices and demand equally high standards from third country producers as required by European producers.

name: Stefano Maullu (PPE).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that animal testing is an act of genuine unacceptable cruelty, and it continues to be so in 80% of the rest of the world. Not in the European Union, where we have, in a farsighted way, anticipated this kind of programme. But I believe, from this point of view, that we need to work a lot to defend those who are now part of our family, therefore companion animals, guinea pigs, all those who, in a very cruel and brutal way, can be subject to this kind of useless experimentation — as well as the Food and Drug Administration reports — in 92% of cases: useless to test cosmetics, useless to allow our particularly advanced companies to be competitive in this global world. That is why I believe that the European Union must strongly pursue, through all the instruments available, the defence of the best practices we have adopted and fight with great determination all those in the rest of the world continue to experiment on animals.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: — Every year in the cosmetic industry more than 100,000 experimental animals die in agony. The numbers are staggering, and from 200,000 there to 500,000 animals. So we hardly talk about animal welfare if we know that a lot of countries even outside the EU still allow animal experiments and marketing cosmetic products, testing for them. And the real dilemma in this is how much time, of course, we will still treat this fact as an embarrassing truth. Europe has a thriving, innovative cosmetic sector, with two million jobs. It was shown that the ban on animal experiments did not in any way jeopardize the development of this sector. However, research in alternative methods has achieved remarkable results. It is also necessary to transfer this model to a global level and to this end commit to global trade and the trade organisation and the UN. I think here as Parliament we can do a lot.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: — Madam President, in my voice I supported the resolution proposing a global ban on animal testing of cosmetic products and their additives. In the European Union, the ban has been in place for five years. However, animal cruelty should not be tolerated anywhere in the world in the 21st century, not just the European Union. Moreover, research shows us that alternative methods are also more efficient. I agree for the European Union to use its influence and actively engage in trying to negotiate an international agreement that would lead to a ban outside the European Union. I appreciate the active role of the European Union in developing alternative methods and I welcome the statement from the Commission, which promised to enforce the clauses on the prohibition of testing in trade agreements animals. I hope that one day the EU will be remembered not only as a pioneer of the testing ban, but also as the driving force behind the world ban.

name: Younous Omarjee (GUE/NGL).
text: — Madam President, in 2013 we banned animal testing for cosmetic products in the European Union. But 5 years later, we find that flaws persist and practice is eventually being relocated and many cosmetic products produced abroad are sold on the European market. It is glad that our European Parliament today is calling for this ban on a global level, but we must go further by banning the sale of these products on the European market. And then I want to say that today we must rise to the demands of our time, it is not permissible that animals have become martyrs or sacrificed for any coquetry whatsoever. This is not worthy of the human species and we must go further to promote alternatives to animal experimentation today.

name: Frédérique Ries (ALDE).
text: — Madam President, rabbits, hamsters, mice, millions of animals are killed every year in laboratories all over the world, whereas today there is no justification for cosmetics. Alternative testing methods exist, faster, more efficient and cheaper, most of the time. Citizens call us, NGOs are all mobilised, consumers choose brands that refuse testing on animals, all tells us that Europeans are sensitive to this animal suffering and want, of course, to reduce it. The European Union banned animal testing just five years ago today. We were the first to do so. Several countries have been walking in our footsteps: Israel, India, New Zealand, soon Australia, Canada, Brazil. It's good, but it's not enough. We now call for the fight to be fought at the United Nations with a convention that is the end of these tests all over the world. Five years now, we have time to expand the virtuous circle. (A few words in English)

name: Sylvie Goddyn (ENF).
text: — Madam President, the ban on animal testing for cosmetics within the European Union has borne fruit. First, this text confirms the positive results of the ban. Secondly, imports of cosmetics from third countries will no longer be the result of animal testing. Thirdly, with this resolution, we are taking responsibility since we reaffirm that alternative solutions exist and that Europe has been using them since 2013. Finally, we go further by calling on the international community and third countries to follow us along this path and to pay particular attention in the context of free trade agreements to respect our legislation in this area. As a co-signatory of this text, I obviously voted in favour of it.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: — Madam President, I believe that the use of animals for the sake of beauty does not suit the beliefs of me, but also a number of Europeans, or I strongly hope that all Europeans in our European area. I am very pleased that the European Union is a leader in this field and that it is really determining the direction, on the other hand, access to our European market for these products, which do not comply with our rules. I think he can be very problematic, to some extent even hypocritical. If we impose a ban on the use of animals in the European area for cosmetic purposes, and then we don't cover these products produced in the surrounding countries, then I think to some extent we are hypocritical. Therefore, I also call for the inaccessibility of our markets for these products and for alternative research into the use of cosmetic purposes without the use of animals.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Madam President, the global ban on animal testing for cosmetics is one of the battles successfully led by my political group, the Socialists and Democrats. The S&D was at the forefront of this issue in 2004 when the European Union stopped the testing of finished cosmetic products, and we were also there when the ban on the importation and sale of any such cosmetics was introduced. However, around 80 countries still allow the testing of cosmetics and toiletries on animals. Causing pain to animals is a great cruelty. We must help our international partners to eliminate this culture of cruelty from their societies. That is important, and it is important that both the UN and Member States promote a cruelty—free approach in their bilateral trade relations. I voted in favour.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D).
text: — Madam President, the sheep and goat sectors have thousands of years of history in Europe. At the same time, however, the European market is increasingly present sheep products mostly from countries such as Australia and New Zealand. The sheep sector needs to be taken out of a future agreement with both countries New Zealand and Australia, because the conditions for producers there are much lower than the European ones, and that puts the European in an uncompetitive position. The new common agricultural policy, unfortunately, provides for less monetary resources in the next programming period. This will enormously have negative consequences on the attractiveness of agriculture, especially for young people. I therefore believe that for young farmers, especially sensitive sectors such as sheep farming and goat farming, a doubling coefficient should be introduced and, accordingly, greater targeted support. I call on sheep farmers and goat farmers in my country Bulgaria to take advantage of market tools, such as mountain products and quality schemes, in order to protect quality products as soon as possible and bring Bulgarian back to the table.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (ENF).
text: — Madam President, the European sheep and goat sectors are in great difficulty. The strong disaffection of this sector and the ageing of livestock farmers combined with the various health crises have deeply destabilized the sector. These sectors have always been the poor parents of livestock and the difficulties they face are exacerbated by the adverse effects of globalization and free trade agreements. This report outlines a number of measures to improve the situation, including a reasonable protected wolf status, lower marking requirements on small farms, reduced requirements for greening of the CAP, an emphasis on outdoor livestock farming and traditional grazing methods, as well as a resuming of because of the presence of these meats in free trade agreements. I therefore supported this report.

name: Dobromir Sośnierz (NI).
text: - Madam President! In the last session in Strasbourg, we learned that EU regulations have destroyed the market for organic products. Now we learn that they have so much destroyed the sheep and goat production in Europe. You've brought it to this by your regulations that on a continent where goat and sheep farming has been part of cultural heritage for centuries, at the moment this market is collapsing rapidly. You've led to the fact that it's more profitable to import by half the world goat meat from New Zealand than to grow on site. Well, and instead of stopping getting into it, now you're going to lecture consumers to buy more goat's milk, and subsidize the goat farm on site. Stop, for God's sake, getting into it, for pig farmers will come in a moment and ask what pigs are inferior to goats, and why they have to endure unfair competition from goat farmers.

name: Curzio Maltese (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in my long career as a journalist I believe that I have never faced such a dark and worrying period for freedom of information. 530 journalists killed are the price paid to freedom of the press in the world, from 2012 to 2016; in nine cases out of ten these are not envoys in distant wars but local chroniclers, as was the case of Daphne Caruana Galizia and Ján Kuciak, the last European victims of this massacre. Violence is not the only threat that looms over freedom of the press, there are others: the concentration of power, the precarious - often miserable - conditions of young journalists, and I thank Barbara Spinelli for bringing this issue back to the heart of the debate. Freedom of the media is a fundamental and central value of our Union, and it is from these values that we must share and not from economic parameters, if we want to secure a future for the European dream.

name: Jasenko Selimovic (ALDE).
text: Madam President! Today, on International Press Freedom Day, it's very good that we're talking about the importance of protecting journalists, but I think unfortunately we need to do much, much more. The reviewing journalism is more necessary than ever in times of these populist fake news. The populist right, however, wants nothing more than for the liberal press to be intimidated on the defensive. There we have a responsibility. No editorial should have to refrain from doing reportage because of threats, which has already happened — not only that but also that one has murdered journalists. The exasperation also has a different face. Even now, we have problems reporting from the war and disaster areas. Only really big editorials can afford to report, because the costs of such an arrangement, for a single reporter and associated team, are simply gigantic. There is therefore a risk that an ever larger part of society is very soon covered by fewer and fewer, very rich editorials, and so media plurality is diminishing even more.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: Madam President, the TV remote is a very good friend of the thinking man. And it is possible to judge the situation of media pluralism if one is in the fortunate position to sit in front of the TV in Hungary, for example, in the very disgraced Hungary, alternating channels in their own country and in the different countries of Western Europe. Well, I am in pain for many people — although I think I will tell our Western European friends nothing new about this — that the situation is reversed just like the European Union is trying to set it up. We, Hungary, Poland, are constantly being abused and accused of having no freedom of expression, no freedom of expression, no freedom of the press.
