Meanwhile, in Western Europe — and I am sure that the majority of Westerners agree that it is true — we are seeing that they are increasingly taking back from freedom of the press, media and freedom of speech mainly with the slogan and reference to hate speech.

name: Francis Zammit Dimech (PPE).
text: — Bla ebda dubju, il-fatt li conomadna dan il-vot illum huwa galija sinifikanti galiex, kif nafu, adna dan il-vot preto iżament fil-jum dinji gЂar-rigward tal-voiarsien tal-libertà tal-istampa u tal-midja. name: Urszula Krupa (ECR).
text: - Madam President! The Own Initiative Report on Pluralism and Media Freedom in the European Union contains a number of important issues. However, some of the records on new forms of restricting freedom of speech, or on the failure to guarantee the conditions of pluralism are unacceptable to me. That's why I abstained. The records ignore the need to restore real conditions in former societies, in totalitarian media, where environments considered hostile by communist authorities were persecuted and their views disregarded or stigmatized. Similarly, changes regarding the treatment of defamation could lead to people being publicly trailed behind the veil of press freedom and media debate. Which is used in fighting otherwise minded or having views far from political correctness, and civil cases incriminate victims. It is also unlawful to invoke the Istanbul Convention, which has not been ratified by a third of the Union States.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D).
text: — Madam President, honourable Members, pluralism, freedom and independence of the media are something we cannot afford to compromise on. They are above all guardians and guarantors of democracy. Unfortunately, we have to recognise that there have been increasingly violations on freedom of speech on the territory of the European Union recently. The murder of Maltese journalist Daphne Caruana Galizia signals a drastic deterioration in media freedom in the European Union. Unfortunately this is not an isolated case. There are also violations on media freedom in my country Bulgaria. The annual ranking of Reporters Without Borders gives Bulgaria the 111st place in freedom of speech. Without surprise, we are at last place in the European Union, with even the countries of the Western Balkans doing better than we do. To be a journalist in Bulgaria is not an easy task nowadays. Backroom bargaining between oligarchs, media and governors is no secret to anyone. The scary thing is when we start to perceive this as something normal.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: — Of course, media pluralism and media freedom are key elements for monitoring democracy, for maintaining democratic standards. Unfortunately, of course, this is also the fact that media freedom is too proportionate to the long arm of capital, which therefore does not hide the behavior of how powerful the force of the media is, and on the other hand, of course, the precarious dependent working relationships of journalists. And that is precisely why, of course, the volume of news that is fake, even so-called hate speech, can also be strengthened. And the consequence is also that this freedom of journalistic work is increasingly being denrowed, and even journalists are not the ones who are supposed to be victims, even those who have paid with their lives. Above all, it is necessary to set decisive standards and therefore clearly make a dividing line between the right of speech, expression and, on the other hand, censorship, because the border is sometimes very thin.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: — Madam President, Ján Kuciak and Daphne Caruana Galizia were killed when exposed transnational octopus arms of organised crime, drug trafficking, corruption and money laundering. We need truth, because only truth and freedom - of the press, first of all, which gives freedom to people - keep us from dictatorship and keep us in democracy. Control: Several European states adopt the Russian model of the press controlled by the oligarchs loyal to power. That is why, under these circumstances, we tabled an amendment for the 2019 budget for the creation of a fund to finance independent investigative journalists. The world needs truth, because only this way can it fight, if it has truth and freedom, against lies, propaganda and dictatorship.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: — Madam President, World Media Freedom Day is a good opportunity to recall the importance of free media, its role, and also to call for the support of public media that have a vital role for the objective awareness of our citizens. We must fight fake news and spreading disinformation campaigns. Therefore, I am glad that, by European means, it is also possible to use public media and media literacy of citizens of all ages. Furthermore, the document calls on Member States for greater involvement of women in the media in order to participate more as experts and in leadership positions. The Commission, together with the Member States, should fight against disinformation campaigns and for media independence. Daphne Galizi, Ján Kuciak — these are the sacrifices they have made to make the media fulfill their role and we should recall their names.

name: Bogdan Andrzej Zdrojewski (PPE).
text: - Madam President! We use the 2013 resolution as well as the Media Pluralism Monitor — an instrument perhaps imperfect, but it's good that it is, and it's good that it is also cited in this report. By contrast, looking at this period between 2013 and the current one, we can no doubt have satisfaction. None, I emphasize: none. Those journalists murdered in Slovakia, Malta or the assassination in Ireland, but also 120 journalists held in prisons in Turkey — that is the facts. On the other hand, we need to remember one more element: we don't know what there is more on the web today, what more is on the internet. Are fake news — false information, fake news, false assessments, or the real ones, requiring solidity, professionalism, real work? On this occasion, I also draw attention to cyber attacks and to propaganda, propaganda in Europe for the benefit of external countries. All of these elements must be made up of more effective mechanisms to control media freedom and truth in the media.

name: Ангел Джамбазки (ECR).
text: — Madam President, I abstained on this report by my colleague Spinelli for several reasons. There is no doubt whatsoever that freedom of the media is key to the level of democracy. There is no doubt that free journalists and free media should be guarded and encouraged. In the world, and in Europe in particular, we are witnessing at the moment of unprecedented pressure on journalists, on publications, on entire sectors of this area. But on the other hand there is the issue of fake news, too. There is a question of how news is delivered to society and societies in general. And this is an essential question that needs to be addressed to both the owners themselves, and to the editors themselves and to those who work in them. On the other hand, this report contains incoherent and unnecessary references to the Istanbul Convention, which one third of the countries in the European Union have not ratified. There is no reason whatsoever to mix the two themes and that is, in my opinion, harmful and wrong.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Madam President, as I said in yesterday's speech, a year before the European elections, the European Parliament and the European Union must ensure that there is pluralism, that the untrue news stops, that propaganda stops, that there is pluralism, that there will be pluralism, that enable us, MEPs and political groups, to be heard in our countries, because this is not the case in Greece, where there is a gagging of both the ECR and our “Greece — The Other Way” movement, where we must ensure our presence in all the media information, to have time commensurate with the strength of our political group, which is the third most powerful political group in the European Parliament, and to stop the silence of our activity. A little while ago, I asked Mr Michel, the Prime Minister of Belgium, who said that Belgium now also stands with Greece in the face of the Turkish threats. Let's see, is this news going to appear in the media or are they going to bury her, too?

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Madam President, the faces of the criminals are more familiar to us than the faces of journalists. Don’t you find this unjust? In the times of fake news and mis-information, journalists must be our new heroes. This is exactly the message that can be seen between the lines of this excellent report to which I have had the honour to contribute with amendments – and not only because I am a former journalist, but because we need to support traditional media. I voted in favour. It is dangerous for our democracy that political information migrates more and more to the domain of Facebook and Twitter, and that is why I particularly welcome the call on the Commission to present a new mechanism on democracy, rule of law and fundamental rights. It should be based on concrete criteria.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: — Madam President, I truly believe that the role of media for democracy is irreplaceable. They are the key independent media and these are facing a whole range of attacks today, they are fake news that is being talked about constantly here. The media is becoming part of hybrid warfare, information warfare. Then there is the problem of self-censorship and even that totally inadmissible censorship. The media faces attacks, there are dozens of journalists in our vicinity, and hundreds of journalists in prison and even in the European area, journalists are being murdered. This is indeed completely inadmissible. I believe that the message could have been better, and I eventually supported it. On the other hand, it contains certain provisions, such as the problematic protection of notifiers in paragraphs 37 and 38. Even given that today is the holiday of journalists, I ultimately supported the report, but I think that the retraction of political motives into such a report is not entirely happy.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE).
text: — Madam President, I have found myself in a dilemma when voting on the report on media freedom. I regard media freedom as a fundamental condition for the functioning of a free society, because only independent media can control government power. I also consider it important that, on European soil, the deliberate and still uninvestigated murder of journalist Ján Kuciak and his fiancee, Martina Kušnírová. But I refuse to abuse these topics to recklessly enforce the so-called Istanbul Convention, with which they have nothing at all to do. Those who do this consciously and deliberately push Christians out of civil society and give the truth to its critics. In the end, I did not support the resolution from the protest against these practices.

name: Dobromir Sośnierz (NI).
text: - Madam President! I voted against this resolution because despite the nice title on protecting media freedom, it contains a lot of harmful typical Brussels regulation in it. He calls, for example, in paragraph one, for media funding in the name of ensuring their independence. No Dear State, if the media is funded by the government, then they will not be independent, they will just be dependent on the government. And that is perhaps the worst kind of dependency there could be for the media. In addition, you intend to mix up on the internet access policy. Well, it'll be like those goats and sheep in a couple of years, that you'll have to bail out a failing sector too soon, if you get involved again. We're going to have to find out something, translate Chinese websites. You want to enter into human rights the right to access the internet — what is it like? That means others will have an obligation to provide that someone with access to the internet if they have the right to access it regardless of whether they paid for it or not. Who's supposed to do that? And why should one man live at the expense of another?

name: La Présidente. –
text: I declare the session of the European Parliament adjourned.
